urn:contentItem:6G6T-MXX3-RSHX-G40R-00000-00Study Findings from Marwadi University Advance Knowledge in Sustainable Development (Forest fire consequences under the influence of changing climate: a systematic review with bibliometric analysis in the context of sustainable development goals)2025-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH - SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENTStudy Findings from Marwadi University Advance Knowledge in Sustainable Development (Forest fire consequences under the influence of changing climate: a systematic review with bibliometric analysis in the context of sustainable development goals)


2025 JUL 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Data detailed on sustainable development have been presented. According to news originating from Marwadi University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires have become a significant research subject among national and international communities due to increasingly favorable climate conditions characterized by prolonged periods conducive to forest fires. However, several studies have been developed worldwide to assess forest fires' conditions, frequency, and intensity."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Marwadi University: "Still, the literature is not transparent globally for forest fires impacting climate or the climate affecting the forest fires. Therefore, the primary objective of this paper is to conduct a comprehensive review using bibliometric analysis and synthesis of the effects of climate change on forest fire activity throughout 2003-2023. The bibliometric data has been collected from the Web of Science (WoS) Core Collection. The results reveal that the USA and Canada occupy the leading positions in maximum production of scientific output with the highest documents and contain the most productive authors' institutes and well-known scholars or authors. Co-authorship overlay analysis showed that Flannigan, M. D. (2.08%) and Bergeron, Y. (1.18%) were the most productive authors with maximum citations and the highest H-index (15 and 11). In addition, we investigated the research strengths of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and their sub-areas at the country and institute levels. Also, we conducted a comprehensive analysis to determine the percentage of literature that contributes to addressing forest fires and climate change in advancing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) throughout the study period. The observation suggests that the existing body of literature significantly contributes to SDGs related to environmental sustainability and climate resilience."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Also, the assessment of the literature's impact on SDGs achievement and awareness spans from 2005 to September 2023. Most earlier studies in this domain demonstrated a significant commitment to SDG 13 (Climate Action), constituting 83.049% of contributions with 886 published documents."
For more information on this research see: Forest fire consequences under the influence of changing climate: a systematic review with bibliometric analysis in the context of sustainable development goals. Discover Sustainability, 2025,6(1):1-16. The publisher for Discover Sustainability is Springer.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1007/s43621-025-00801-0.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ramesh Kumar, Marwadi University Research Center, Department of Civil Engineering, Marwadi University. Additional authors for this research include Prity S. Pippal, Rajesh Kumar, Atar Singh, Shruti Singh, Pankaj Kumar, Susen Shrestha.
Keywords for this news article include: Marwadi University, Climate Change, Global Warming, Sustainability Research, Sustainable Development.

urn:contentItem:6GPT-K913-RS6N-61JJ-00000-00Mask ban for forest fire crews lifted2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisMAIN NEWSScience DeskPart APg. 1Mask ban for forest fire crews liftedU.S. agency reverses a decades-long rule amid concerns about smoke and cancer.Susanne Rust

The U.S. Forest Service has announced it is reversing a ban on federal firefighters wearing masks, and will give crews protective N95s as they battle increasingly intense fires across the nation.

For decades, the agency argued their use made firefighters vulnerable to heat exhaustion.

Other wildfire-prone nations, such as Canada, Greece and Australia, provide their firefighters with masks to prevent lung damage and smoke-related diseases, including cancer and organ failure -- and have not seen increases in heatstroke among the crews.

The policy will have little bearing on local and regional urban firefighters, such as those in Los Angeles and Los Angeles County.

"We are actually encouraged to wear them," said Jonathan Torres, engineer and spokesman for the Los Angeles County Fire Department.

"There are chemicals that are unknown to us that are part of our work," as buildings and infrastructure burn, he said. Masks provide some protection against harmful smoke particles and chemicals released when plastics, upholstery and synthetic building materials burn.

This week, the forest agency announced it has stockpiled roughly 80,000 N95 masks and will include them as part of the equipment it provides for large fires.

The decision came after a series of New York Times reports that detailed the Forest Service's decades-long refusal to require, or even offer, masks to its crews, despite recommendations from state and federal health agencies, and a growing body of evidence that wildfire smoke is harming firefighter health.

"To provide masks, and even require masks, is an implicit admission of the health hazards of smoke," said Timothy Ingalsbee, executive director of Firefighters United for Safety, Ethics and Ecology, an organization that promotes the health and safety of wildland firefighters.

Ingalsbee and others say the Forest Service's reluctance to encourage mask wearing was probably motivated by concern it would be admitting that smoke poses dangers and risks to its crews.

Research shows that firefighters have a 9% higher risk of getting a cancer diagnosis than the general public, and 14% higher risk of dying from cancer. Crews may be exposed to smoke and other toxins believed to cause cancer, such as benzene, phenols and heavy metals, while fighting fires.

Federal lawmakers are now working on safety legislation to protect federal and contract wildland firefighters, and have sent a series of letters to the Forest Service criticizing what they call its decades-long neglect.

Reports suggest that "that federal agencies are neglecting their duty to protect the health of wildland firefighters," wrote Reps. Jared Huffman (D-San Rafael), Maxine Dexter (D-Ore.) and Joe Neguse (D-Colo.) in a letter to Forest Service chief Tom Schultz. "Neglecting the health of current firefighters will make future recruitment harder and leave our communities vulnerable."

On Tuesday, they grilled Schultz at a House oversight meeting.

Huffman urged Schultz to warn workers about the dangers of smoke exposure: "Chief, do you feel like the Forest Service is doing everything that it can to make the safety risk of smoke inhalation known to firefighters?"

Gov. Gavin Newsom and the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection also announced Tuesday that the state will be funding research designed to examine how smoke and other occupational exposures may increase cancer risk in firefighters.

The research, which includes a collaboration among scientists and experts at UCLA, UC Davis and Cal Fire, is backed by nearly $9.7 million in state funding and will include 3,500 firefighters from departments across the state over a two-year period.

The study comes at a time when the Trump administration has made drastic cuts to cancer research.

"It's California at our best: our world-class public universities teaming up with the women and men who put their lives on the line to protect others -- all in an effort to improve health outcomes for all," Newsom said in a statement.

The study will include a focus on the exposures and biological changes that occurred in firefighters who responded to the Eaton and Palisades fires in Los Angeles.

Ingalsbee said that masks are not always appropriate when fighting fires -- there are activities, such as traipsing up and down steep terrain when a N95 mask can get gummed up with debris and sweat and make it difficult for a firefighter to breathe. However, he said, the vast majority of the time, when firefighters are at their base camps, where it's often smoky, or driving along dusty, sandy roads, masks could go a long way to protect their lungs, reducing exposure.

"There are times when masks are unsuitable and firefighters overheat and they are uncomfortable," he said. "But there's a lot of times when they'd be very useful in limiting their exposure. And maybe could save some lives."

PHOTO: U.S. FOREST SERVICE firefighter Alan Gudino, right, shields his face while battling the Madre fire in July. PHOTOGRAPHER:Noah Berger Associated Press

urn:contentItem:6GMG-TWK3-RT3V-N2XK-00000-00UPDATED: Here's where fire bans are in effect across Ottawa Valley2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATED: Here's where fire bans are in effect across Ottawa ValleyOlivia Barrett

UPDATE (Aug. 29, 1:20 p.m.): Recent rainfall has lifted open-air burning bans in Mississippi Mills, Carleton Place, and Arnprior. Beckwith has downgraded its fire ban to campfires only.

Amid dry conditions and fire danger ratings from the Ministry of Natural Resources, municipalities across the Ottawa Valley are putting fire bans in place.

Here's what you need to knowAccording to the ministry's forest fire information map, several communities have an extreme forest fire danger rating. These include Renfrew, Arnprior, Carleton Place, Mississippi Mills, Township of Greater Madawaska, parts of Township of Admaston/Bromley, parts of the Township of Bonnechere Valley and the Township of McNab/Braeside.The County of Renfrew encourages residents to check with their municipality for updates regarding local fires bans.McNab/Braeside has put a level 2 total fire ban in place effective Aug. 11. Carleton Place has lifted its open-air burning ban effective Aug. 29. Refer to bylaw 21-2004 to ensure you are in compliance with municipal regulations before you burn.North Algona Wilberforce has issued a total fire ban effective Aug. 8.Mississippi Mills has eased its total fire ban to Level 3 - High Risk as of Aug. 28. Open-air burning is permitted but use extreme caution.Greater Madawaska has a level 2 total fire ban effective Aug. 8North Grenville announced a total burn ban on July 29. Drummond/North Elmsley and Tay Valley have a level 3 full fire ban effective Aug. 10. Beckwith has downgraded its fire ban to campfires only effective Aug. 29. Small, recreational campfires are now permitted. No other open-air burning is allowed.Pembroke has issued a full ban on recreational fires effective Aug. 11. All permits issued by the city are suspended.Renfrew has a total burn ban in effect as of Aug. 11.Arnprior has lifted the municipal-wide fire ban effective Aug. 29. The temporary suspension of all issued burn permits for 2025 has been removed and applications currently filed with the town will be processed and administered beginning on Tuesday, Sept. 2.Smiths Falls has announced that all open burning is prohibited effective Aug. 11.Lanark County, including Perth, has a total fire ban effective Aug. 11.United Counties of Leeds and Grenville issued a total fire ban effective Aug. 6.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BPK3-RS5Y-N31F-00000-00EU: forest fires have burned more than 1 million hectares2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisEU: forest fires have burned more than 1 million hectares


Forest fires have burned more than 1 million hectares of land in the European Union (EU) so far this year, the highest number since official records began in 2006.


According to EU data, a total of 1,028,000 hectares have been devastated by fires as of this Tuesday (26) - an area larger than Cyprus and than the total recorded in any year, according to the EU's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
Related news:

Forest fires in Europe hit tourist spots .

Fires in Spain have already affected 343,000 hectares, an annual record.

Spain records third death in firefighting.


The previous record was set in 2017, when the area burned by forest fires was around 998,000 hectares.
Spain and Portugal were the hardest hit and together accounted for around two thirds of the area burned in the EU. The EFFIS data shows a sharp increase in forest fires between August 5 and 19, a period that coincided with a 16-day heatwave on the Iberian Peninsula.
The heatwave ended last week, after fueling fires that killed at least eight people in the two countries and forced the closure of roads and rail services.
However, ten forest fires are still active in the Castilla y León region of Spain, where around 700 people have been evacuated, while flames continue in the northern regions of Galicia and Asturias.
In Portugal, cooler temperatures have brought some relief, and a fire in Piódão was extinguished on Monday after 12 days. With more than 60,000 hectares burnt, Piódão is the largest forest fire ever recorded in the country.
Climate change is making forest fires, heatwaves and droughts more frequent and severe, although prevention measures, such as clearing dry vegetation, have played an important role in controlling fires.
Forest fires in the EU have emitted 38 million tons of carbon dioxide so far this year, according to EFFIS. This is more than in the same period of any year on record, putting 2025 on course to break the annual record of 41 million tons.
(Additional reporting by Andrey Khalip and Inti Landauro)

urn:contentItem:6GKK-1JV3-RWB2-90BF-00000-00Wildfires burn over 1 million hectares in EU, 4 times more than last year2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisNEWSWildfires burn over 1 million hectares in EU, 4 times more than last yearEUROPE WILDFIRESABSTRACT

Brussels, Aug 26 (EFE).- Over a million hectares (nearly the size of Jamaica) have burned across the European Union in 2025, four times the area destroyed in the same period last year, according to new data released Tuesday by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

FULL TEXT

Brussels, Aug 26 (EFE).- Over a million hectares (nearly the size of Jamaica) have burned across the European Union in 2025, four times the area destroyed in the same period last year, according to new data released Tuesday by the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

Between Jan. 1 and Aug. 26, the EU recorded 1,851 wildfires, compared to 1,185 in 2024.

The fires released 38.37 million tons of CO2 into the atmosphere, over three times last year's emissions of 11.46 million tons.

"This year's fire season is unprecedented in scope and intensity," said an EFFIS spokesperson.

Spain and Portugal worst hit

Spain has suffered the heaviest damage, with 413,992 hectares destroyed in 268 fires, accounting for 40% of the total burned area in the EU.

The figure already surpasses the country's annual average of 203 fires between 2006 and 2024.

Portugal is the second most affected, where 270,450 hectares have burned across 155 fires so far this year.

"The Mediterranean remains the epicenter of Europe's wildfire crisis," EFFIS noted in its latest bulletin.

Rising fire risks across Europe

EFFIS forecasts varying fire risks across Europe through Sep. 1.

The outlook shows a "low" risk in France, southern Germany, Italy, and much of the Balkans, but significantly higher risks elsewhere.

In the Iberian Peninsula, conditions are expected to ease in the north, but risk levels will remain "high" or "very high" across much of Spain and Portugal, with "extreme" or "very extreme" danger in southeastern Spain.

The bulletin also warns of extreme risks in Belgium, the Netherlands, northern Germany, southern Poland, Czechia, Slovakia, Hungary, and Romania, as well as "high" risk in Sicily, Greece, and western Turkey. EFE

In Portugal, cooler temperatures have brought some relief, and a fire in Piódão was extinguished on Monday after 12 days. With more than 60,000 hectares burnt, Piódão is the largest forest fire ever recorded in the country.
Climate change is making forest fires, heatwaves and droughts more frequent and severe, although prevention measures, such as clearing dry vegetation, have played an important role in controlling fires.
Forest fires in the EU have emitted 38 million tons of carbon dioxide so far this year, according to EFFIS. This is more than in the same period of any year on record, putting 2025 on course to break the annual record of 41 million tons.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RW6H-B1PX-00000-00Quito installs cabinet against forest fires in Nayón2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisQuito installs cabinet against forest fires in Nayón


Nayón, one of the parishes most affected by last year's fires, has a forestfire fighting cabinet as of Friday, August 22, 2025. The equipment is located in a strategic point of easy access and seeks to strengthen the firstcommunityresponse to emergencies.


Quito lost US$20 million to forest fires in 2024
The city faced one of its worst fire seasons a year ago. According to the Chamber of Commerce, losses reached US$20 million.
Emergency crews attended 340 fires that devastated 2,274 hectares in different sectors. Among the hardest hit were LosChillos, Tumbaco, Cumbayá, Nayón, Chilibulo, ElPanecillo and the Auqui hill.
Ninety-nine percent of these events were of humanorigin. Firefighters identified agriculturalburnings, garbage burning and bonfires during excursions as the main causes.
Forestry Cabinet to prevent new fires in Nayón
The commander of the QuitoFireDepartment, EstebanCardenas, explained that the new cabinet serves for prevention and firstresponse in criticalareas.
He recalled that Nayón is one of the mostat-risk areas due to the ease with which firespreads on its hillsides.
How the forest fire fighting cabinet works
The equipment consists of a metalstructure mounted on a hydrant. It contains three 30-meter hoses, two pressurehoses and a hydrant with two outlets.
With these implements, residents can contain a fireoutbreak and gain time until the arrivalof firefighters.
Quito reinforces its prevention plan
Since March 2025, the FireDepartment has been executing an operational plan to reduce risks.
It includes patrols in vulnerablesectors, vegetation clearing, thermalsensors and the installation of forestcabinets.
The District has 70 stations, more than 50 trucks and up to 400 personnel available every day.
Nayón, known as the Garden of Quito for its diversity of ornamentalplants and its temperate climate of 23 °C, becomes one of the firstparishes to incorporate this community tool against forestfires.

urn:contentItem:6H2N-SWK3-RRKB-N0XP-00000-00Our Readers Views2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisLETTERS TO EDITORPg. A5Our Readers Views

Managed forests reduce risks

The editorial "Rethink logging in protected federal forests" (In Our View, Sept. 12) is not only misleading but exposes serious errors concerning logging in Forest Service "managed" forests.

These forests are almost impenetrable because of decades of neglect. I have hiked the Gifford Pinchot National Forest for decades and it is sad to see it become more and more choked with brush. Large grazing meadows have disappeared, leaving little habitat for wildlife to use.

Managed forests reduce risks
The editorial "Rethink logging in protected federal forests" (In Our View, Sept. 12) is not only misleading but exposes serious errors concerning logging in Forest Service "managed" forests.
These forests are almost impenetrable because of decades of neglect. I have hiked the Gifford Pinchot National Forest for decades and it is sad to see it become more and more choked with brush. Large grazing meadows have disappeared, leaving little habitat for wildlife to use.


Professionally managed logging, contrary to Sen. Maria Cantwell's erroneous comments, mitigates both carbon and forest fire concerns. Mature trees hold the carbon they've drawn in, but their ability to continue to draw in carbon is almost nil. But the young trees planted after logging will increasingly draw carbon for about 50 years.
A patchwork of recently logged and aging logged areas greatly reduces forest fire risk by having gated roads allowing quick response by firefighters and a reduction in the current 2 million acres of brush-choked forest.
John H. Roscoe
Battle Ground
Keep Perez in Congress
Who in this congressional district wants to elect a Republican who will pretend to heed electors' needs? One who will kowtow to the greed and mistruths popular among today's Republicans? One who will take away our health care, vaccines, education, due process, and raise prices of just about everything and kill our democracy?
Who will elect that Republican? Those Democrats, progressives and nonthinkers who do not vote at all because some of Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez's votes are stuck in their idealistic craws. Or vote for an alternative who cannot win, who will take votes from the incumbent Democrat.
Earlier in Perez's career, I too was disappointed in her votes. She reasoned the bills wouldn't fix the root of the problem, and I agreed with her, but not her votes.
Anyone who pays attention to politics knows the first years of new legislators are a steep learning curve. Those who have followed Perez recently have seen her begin to understand she must represent the entire district, as well as what it means to honor her oath to protect our democracy.
We must keep her in the House. Give her more opportunity to develop. Vote for Marie.
Marj Casswell
VANCOUVER
Adhere to Third Commandment
Many letters to the editor quote Scripture to justify their beliefs. The MAGA cult often justify their positions as "ordained" by Jesus   Trump being the model of Christ in action.
In that spirit, let's look at the very Ten Commandments they want to lead our school curriculum, justifying many hateful positions as they interpret "scripture" and advocate for persecution of nonbelievers.
Refer to Commandment No. 3, which is often interpreted as simply a prohibition against cursing. There is much more. For those who justify their actions as "God-given," they should show caution when using the "Lord's name in vain."
As you circulate messages of anger and hate, exclusion and revenge   justification for the elite entitled white Christians, reflect on the "law": The commandment is directed against the abuse of the name of God, where God's name is used to support the truth of the statement being sworn to. Think about this as you post or speak, citing God as support   is that a sin?
Judy I. Veazie
VANCOUVER
Support Garber for charter review
The charter review commission is an elected group of citizens who review the county charter and place amendments on the ballot to improve the structure of local government. This nonpartisan role requires commissioners who prioritize county citizens over politics.
Cathie Garber fits this description. Cathie was Clark County elections director for 14 years, giving her a deep understanding of how local government operates within the framework of state laws and our Constitution. Her background includes working with Democrats and Republicans, demonstrating her ability to collaborate with individuals holding different viewpoints.
We need Cathie Garber on our charter review commission.
Les Stark
LA CENTER

urn:contentItem:6GSB-6DN3-RRPP-X4NM-00000-00Officials insist there's no evidence timber industry worsens wildfires2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSOfficials insist there's no evidence timber industry worsens wildfiresJohn Chilibeck, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Daily Gleaner

Michelle Conroy says she appreciates all the work the province's firefighters have put into protecting Miramichi, as wildfires raged out of controljust north of the city for the better part of last month.

But the Progressive Conservative MLA for Miramichi East also wonders if their employer, the Department of Natural Resources, might have unintentionally made conditions in the forests worse by encouraging herbicide spraying so that New Brunswick's powerful timber industry could have softwood plantations.

"When we kill the broadleaf and replace hardwood with softwood, pine needles burn faster, they burn hotter," she said during a session of the standing committee on climate change and environmental stewardship at the legislature last week. "I've thrown pine trees in fire pits and seen how fast they burn."

The idea that the ecosystem could had been thrown "out of balance," in Conroy's words, was addressed by Deputy Minister Cade Libby.

"Your comment is one we've heard quite a few times, especially this summer as we've experienced and come through probably one of the larger fire seasons that we've seen," Libby said. 

"Yes, herbicides target broad-leafed plants and it's to reduce that competition out there. But I will say this: a working forest is a great way to mitigate forest fire risk." 

The deputy minister said timber cutters use forestry roads that act as fire breaks and that they work on parcels of land that have forests of various types and age classes that have less fuel load than virgin, old-growth forests do.

Chris Norfolk, the assistant deputy minister, told Conroy he had looked at different inventories of New Brunswick's woods over the years. The oldest he found, the first comprehensive inventory of its type, showed that in New Brunswick in 1954, about 43 per cent of the woods were primarily softwood.

Today, that figure sits at 43.5 per cent, not much different than 71 years ago, despite the use of herbicide spraying, tree planting and modern silviculture practices.

He acknowledged at a local level that can look very different some plantations have virtually no hardwood because of efforts to eradicate it, whereas in the past forests that were primarily softwood also had hardwoods mixed in.

And Norfolk admitted he wasn't sure what burns fastest - the natural Acadian forest, which has 32 native species of trees, versus pure softwood plantations.

Most of the research on forest fires and what burns fastest and hottest has been conducted in Central and Western Canada, the official said.

"We need a better understanding how our local fuel types, including plantations and other areas that have received silviculture, how they behave when we experience forest fire conditions like the ones we've experienced this summer," Norfolk said.

To that end, the department has received conditional funding from Ottawa over the next couple of years, in partnership with the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, to study the problem through what Norfolk called aliving lab model.

Herbicide spraying in New Brunswick's public woods is a hot topic. The chemicals have been widely applied over the past decades by timber firms, the railways, the military and the public electrical utility NB Power to kill unwanted vegetation on vast tracts. Some people fear they could harm humans and wildlife.

The officials told the committee that the timber and paper industries need herbicides to keep costs in line. Often called New Brunswick's cornerstone industry, wood products are worth more than $3 billion in annual exports. The industry, directly and indirectly, employs about 26,000 people, often in smaller communities where jobs are otherwise scarce.

The department officials said they followed Health Canada's lead on herbicides. Its studies show that if the spray products are used according to the label, they are safe.

In addition, the province has put on extra layers of safety to try to address public concerns. For instance, it recently increased the setback for aerial spraying from homes from 155 metres to 500 metres, although a request by the all-party committee in 2021 for it to be a one-kilometre setback has been ruled out.

The officials pointed out that companies are forced to post signs stating when they sprayed on trails that lead into the woods. About 15,000 hectares are re-planted and sprayed each year, at a cost of $3 million to taxpayers. To put that in perspective, one football field is about one hectare.

Companies that operate in the woods say the chemicals help because they prevent unwanted vegetation from growing, and they're much cheaper to apply than physically cutting and removing all that plants.

For example, timber firms use them in selected areas to help a new tree stand grow to a certain height without facing competition from what they consider weeds. Newly planted areas are generally sprayed once, sometimes twice as red maples are harder to kill than most deciduous trees.

Rail companies apply them to clear the sides of tracks, to prevent accidents and wildfires. 

NB Power once was a big user of glyphosate underneath its nearly 28,000 kilometres of powerlines but since 2023, it has discontinued the use of glyphosate-based herbicides. However, it continues to use other herbicides in limited quantities along transmission rights of way.

Still, herbicide opponents are frustrated that some recommendations made by the committee four years ago are only now being acted upon. A study that was supposed be done within 12 months comparing the cost of herbicide spraying with manual cutting won't be completed till March 2027. That's a six-year timeline.

"I would like them to explain why they didn't do the work we asked them to do," Green MLA Megan Mitton told reporters afterwards. "The cost-benefit analysis and how to do that transition is really important."

Natural Resources Minister John Herron, who sat listening during the committee session, told journalists that his Liberal government had only been in power 10 months.

"We've made some progress over the last couple of months," he said. "I come from a background or tradition where legislators and parliaments matter and giving proper attention to legislatures and committee reports is the work of government. Having more speed, having more fulsome answers is a good thing."

However, Herron defended the use of herbicide spraying, saying he'd follow the science. He did not explain why his department had refused to increase setbacks from homes to one kilometre, one of the committee's demands, only pointing out that the biggest timber firm in New Brunswick, J.D. Irving, Limited, had told him it already uses a one-kilometre minimum setback.

He said he hadn't spoken to other timber firms about the issue and didn't know what kind of setbacks they use.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-WGJ3-RRPD-V1B4-00000-00Russian drones kill rescuer in Nizhyn, injure two others2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisRUSSIA NEWSRussian drones kill rescuer in Nizhyn, injure two others

A 45-year-old first responder was killed in a Russian drone attack on the city of Nizhyn in Ukraine's Chernihiv Oblast late on Sep. 17, regional Governor Vyacheslav Chaus reported on Telegram the following morning.

Russian forces targeted a State Emergency Service (SES) unit with Shahed and Geran drones, killing Master Sergeant of the Civil Protection Service Oleksandr Hula.

A second strike hit a fire truck that had arrived to respond to the initial attack. Two other rescuers, aged 36 and 31, were injured.

"Cynical and cruel: on Rescuer's Day, they attacked the rescuers," Chaus said.

The overnight assault extended beyond Nizhyn. In the Novgorod-Siverskyi district, artillery fire damaged a grain storage facility and a farm warehouse. In the Korukivka district, a drone strike sparked a forest fire. Overall, Russian forces shelled the oblast 22 times in the past 24 hours, hitting 14 different settlements.

Ukraine's Air Force said Russia launched 75 drones across the country on the night of Sep. 18, of which air defenses shot down 48.

urn:contentItem:6GSB-9KK3-RSFR-80KG-00000-00Russian attacks SES unit in Nizhyn, killing 1 rescuer, injuring 2 - Chaus2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisRUSSIA NEWSRussian attacks SES unit in Nizhyn, killing 1 rescuer, injuring 2 - Chaus

KYIV. 18 Sept (Interfax-Ukraine) - One rescuer was killed and two others were injured in an attack by Russian occupiers on the city of Nizhyn, Chernihiv Regional Military Administration head Vycheslav Chaus said on Telegram on Thursday morning.

"One of the units of the State Emergency Service (SES) was hit by Shahed UAVs. Cynical and cruel: on the day of the rescuer - on rescuers. Unfortunately, the 45-year-old emergency worker died from his injuries. My condolences to his family and colleagues," Chaus said.

In addition, a 36-year-old rescuer was injured. He is currently under the supervision of doctors in a metropolitan hospital. Another rescuer is in the trauma department. The injured person is 31 years old.

In addition to Nizhyn, a farm in the Novhorod-Siverskyi district was damaged by Russian shelling. A granary and a warehouse were damaged as a result of artillery shelling.

In the Koriukiv district of the Chernihiv region, a forest fire broke out due to a UAV attack - the fire was extinguished.

In total, over the past 24 hours, the aggressor shelled the territory of the region 22 times: 48 attacks were recorded in 14 settlements of the region.

As reported, on September 14, an oil depot and a gas station were destroyed as a result of a UAV strike on Nizhyn. Four rescuers were injured during the liquidation of the consequences of the shelling, three of them as a result of the Russian strike.

urn:contentItem:6GSB-NSH3-RRX9-T115-00000-00Russia strikes SESU unit on professional holiday: rescuer killed, two injured2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisRussia strikes SESU unit on professional holiday: rescuer killed, two injured

Yesterday, September 17, on professional holiday, Rescuer's Day, russian occupiers attacked emergency workers in Nizhyn, Chernihiv Region. As a result of the strike on the State Emergency Service of Ukraine (SESU) unit, a rescuer was killed, and two more were injured.

This was reported by the head of the Chernihiv Regional Military Administration, Vyacheslav Chaus.

"The aggressor attacked Nizhyn again. It used drones - Shaheds and Geran - to strike one of the SESU units. Cynical and cruel: on Rescuer's Day - to strike rescuers. Unfortunately, the 45-year-old emergency worker died from his injuries," the report says.

A 36-year-old rescuer was also injured and is under the supervision of doctors in a metropolitan hospital. In addition, the 31-year-old rescuer is in the traumatology department.

In addition, the Chernihiv Region has also suffered other attacks - the enemy hit a farm in the Novhorod-Siverskyi district with artillery. The granary and warehouse were damaged.

In the Koriukivskyi district, a forest fire broke out due to a UAV attack - the fire was extinguished.

In total, over the past 24 hours, the aggressor shelled the Chernihiv Region 22 times. 48 attacks in 14 settlements of the region.

As Ukrainian News Agency earlier reported, the day before, the russian occupiers again struck with drones at Ukrainian rescuers who were extinguishing a fire at the site of the previous hit of a russian strike drone in the Kyiv Region.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-K083-RRXN-W4BY-00000-00Indonesia: President Prabowo Subianto Leads Cabinet Meeting on Forest Fire Mitigation from Hambalang Residence2025-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisIndonesia: President Prabowo Subianto Leads Cabinet Meeting on Forest Fire Mitigation from Hambalang Residence

Key Highlights:

* President Prabowo Subianto led a Cabinet Meeting via video conference to monitor forest and land fires and implement mitigation measures.

* The area affected by fires has decreased significantly over the past two years, with a 33.3% reduction in 2024 compared to 2023, and a further drop to 8,95 hectares in August 2025.

* President Prabowo Subianto emphasized the importance of law enforcement against those responsible for land and forest burning and urged all parties to remain vigilant and prepared for the dry season.

Original Press Release:

Aug. 3 -- Cabinet Secretariat of the Republic of Indonesia issued the following news release:

President Prabowo Subianto led a Cabinet Meeting via video conference from his residence in Hambalang in Bogor regency over the weekend.

The primary agenda was to monitor the potential forest and land fires and to implement appropriate mitigation measures.

In his written statement, Cabinet Secretary Teddy Indra Wijaya explained that President Prabowo Subianto expressed his appreciation to the Ministries and all teams involved in the mitigation efforts.

"The President expressed his appreciation to Ministry of the Environment and other relevant ministries, as well as the teams, for their efforts in preventing and mitigating potential forest fires across the country," wrote the Cabinet Secretary.

Teddy also mentioned that the President highlighted the area affected by fires, noting that it has decreased significantly over the past two years.

"According to the data, there has been a reduction in the area affected by fires. Compared to 2023, the fire-affected area decreased significantly by 33.3%, reaching 376,805 hectares in 2024. Furthermore, data from August 2025 indicates that the total fire-affected area dropped to just 8,95 hectares," said the Cabinet Secretary.

Teddy added that President Prabowo Subianto also stressed the importance of law enforcement against anyone responsible for land and forest burning, while urging all parties to remain vigilant and prepared for the challenges posed by the upcoming dry season.

"Law enforcement will be strictly applied to anyone responsible for land and forest burning. The President also reminded the teams at both the central and the regional levels of government to stay prepared. According to data from the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency (MCGA), the dry season is expected to continue until August 2025," said the Cabinet Secretary.

For the record, the meeting was part of the Government's initiative to ensure that mitigation measures are implemented effectively amid the challenges posed by climate change and extreme weather, which may increase the risk of land and forest fires in certain regions of Indonesia.

[Category: Capital Goods, Aerospace and Defense, Events]

Source: Cabinet Secretariat of the Republic of Indonesia

urn:contentItem:6GXT-RRF3-RVB0-3556-00000-00Record-Breaking 2024 Amazon Fires Drive Unprecedented Carbon Emissions And Ecosystem Degradation2025-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisRecord-Breaking 2024 Amazon Fires Drive Unprecedented Carbon Emissions And Ecosystem DegradationEurasia Review

A new study by researchers at the European Commission's Joint Research Centre reveals that the Amazon rainforest has just undergone its most devastating forest fire season in over two decades, which triggered record-breaking carbon emissions and exposed the region's growing ecological fragility despite a slowing trend in deforestation.

The 2024 fires released an estimated 791 million tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, which roughly equates to the annual emissions of Germany. This marks a sevenfold increase from the average of the previous two years.

According to the study published in Biogeosciences, 3.3 million hectares of Amazon forest were impacted by fires last year alone. This extraordinary surge in fire activity is likely driven by a combination of extreme drought stress exacerbated by climate change, forest fragmentation, and land-use mismanagement (e.g., escape fires or criminal fires by land grabbers), leading to significant forest degradation. For the first time in the analysis covering 2022-2024, fire-induced degradation has overtaken deforestation as the primary driver of carbon emissions in the Amazon.

This research draws on a sophisticated satellite-based methodology that overcomes many of the limitations of previous global fire datasets. By combining data from the Tropical Moist Forest monitoring system with the Global Wildfire Information System and filtering out false signals caused by agricultural fires or cloud cover, scientists were able to detect and verify fire-driven forest degradation with a novel level of precision.

The geographical spread of the fires was equally alarming. In Brazil, 2024 marked the highest level of emissions from forest degradation on record. In Bolivia, fires affected over 9% of the country's remaining intact forest cover, which is a dramatic blow to a region that has historically served as a vital biodiversity reservoir and carbon sink.

To ensure scientific rigor and transparency, the researchers used a Monte Carlo simulation framework to estimate carbon emissions and their uncertainties. across variables such as above-ground biomass density, combustion completeness, and the percentage of forest cover affected by fire. The resulting confidence intervals adhere to Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) best practices and offer a robust benchmark for tracking the carbon consequences of forest fires in tropical regions.

While past reports have highlighted the dangers of deforestation, this study spotlights a more insidious threat: fire-driven degradation that erodes forest integrity without necessarily clearing it. Degraded forests may look intact from above, but they lose a significant portion of their biomass and ecological function. Unlike clear-cut areas, these degraded forests often fall through the cracks of national accounting systems and international policy frameworks.

The study calls for immediate and coordinated action to reduce fire use, strengthen forest protection policies, and support local and Indigenous stewardship efforts. It also highlights the need for enhanced international climate finance mechanisms that recognize and address forest degradation, not just deforestation.

urn:contentItem:6GXV-2NH3-RT71-H05J-00000-00Homecoming bonfire replaced with light show due to statewide burn ban - The Dartmouth2025-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Homecoming bonfire replaced with light show due to statewide burn ban - The DartmouthIsabel Menna

Published October 9, 2025

The College canceled the annual Homecoming bonfire because of a statewide outdoor burn ban, according to an Oct. 3 email from interim dean of undergraduate student affairs Anne Hudak. Instead, the College will host a light and laser show with music performed by student DJs.

"By reimagining our tradition, we are respecting community safety and environmental responsibility while creating a new and unforgettable experience for this year's Homecoming weekend," Hudak wrote.

Over the past few months, a severe drought hascoveredlarge swaths of northern New England. Republican Gov. Kelly Ayotte issued the ban on Sept. 22, making open fires unlawful until conditions improve.

This is the first time the bonfire has beencanceledsince 2020, when the state banned public gatherings during the pandemic.

In an interview with The Dartmouth, Hudak said that while the news may be "disappointing," she expects the opening night of Homecoming to "still be a celebration of class unity, pride, and creativity."

"Personally, I'm excited to see our students' talents and creativity at the center of the light and laser show," Hudak said.

Dartmouth's executive director of conferences and events EJ Kiefer said many popular Homecoming traditions will remain.

"We wanted as many of the elements of what's in a traditional Homecoming weekend around the Green to be preserved," Kiefer said.

State forest fire supervisor for the New Hampshire Forest Protection Bureau chief Steven Sherman said the burn ban followed "the driest summer ever recorded for the state."

"It was not just the lack of rainfall that contributed to the increased wildfire risk, but also the very low relative humidity levels," Sherman said. "Embers from a large fire such as Dartmouth's could blow off the Green and land on a nearby lawn or wooded area and start a fire that could cause loss of property or injure someone."

Some students expressed disappointment at the College's decision. Gabe Umlas '29 said he was "pretty devastated" when he heard the bonfire was canceled.

"I was really sad," Umlas said. "I know it's a really fun event that past years have done."

Mackenzie Froedge '29 said she had looked forward to experiencing a class-wide tradition, after many high school traditions were canceled due to COVID.

"I was excited to finally have a real tradition in college ... when [the bonfire] was canceled, I thought, 'oh, it's happening all over again,'" Froedge said.

Sarah Hochman '28, who experienced last year's bonfire as a freshman, said she understood the environmental concerns but still found the change disappointing.

"It's a memory I really treasure," Hochman recalled. "It can be pretty disappointing, especially for the first-years, to know you're not going to be able to share those experiences with other Dartmouth students and alumni."

urn:contentItem:6GN5-YB73-RS08-03K5-00000-00Research from Institute of BioEconomy Provide New Insights into Forestry (Drought models for the study of the vegetation moisture content; analysis of performance of different models in two mediterranean ecosystems for application in forest ...)2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - FORESTRYResearch from Institute of BioEconomy Provide New Insights into Forestry (Drought models for the study of the vegetation moisture content; analysis of performance of different models in two mediterranean ecosystems for application in forest ...)


2025 SEP 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- A new study on forestry is now available. According to news reporting from the Institute of BioEconomy by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Vegetation water content is one of the most important parameters of vegetation status and health, and consequently a natural element that regulates several ecosystems worldwide; moreover, considering vegetation as fuel, this variable is related to wildfires."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Institute of BioEconomy: "Forest fires and vegetation resistance to ignition during periods of drought are both strictly related to climate characteristics of the area. The contribution of this work is to evaluate the performance of vegetation drought models using field measured data (data related to local adaptation and phenotypic plasticity), data usually lacking. In the present work, moisture content of shrub vegetation and live foliage (fine fuels) were detected by field measurements of in Tuscany (Italy). In two plots of Quercus ilex L. and mixed broadleaves forest, seasonal and inter-annual variations of live fine fuels of several species are analyzed. The selected species constitute two sets (shrubs and trees) of vegetation typology characterized by a representative seasonal variability in mediterranean ecosystems. From nearby stations meteorological data were collected in each study area for the evaluation of fuel moisture indicators, including the Drought Code (DC) used in the Canadian Forest Fire Danger Rating System."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The results of the present work have shown that for the summer season the slow response of live fine fuel moisture content (LFMC) to meteorological conditions (namely to precipitation), was well described by the DC. Empirical correlations between LFMC and DC for each species and site are proposed."
For more information on this research see: Drought models for the study of the vegetation moisture content; analysis of performance of different models in two mediterranean ecosystems for application in forest fire prevention. Central European Forestry Journal, 2025,71(3):170-180. (Central European Forestry Journal - https://www.degruyter.com/view/j/forj). The publisher for Central European Forestry Journal is Sciendo.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.2478/forj-2025-0006.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Bonora Laura, 1National Research Council of Italy, Institute of BioEconomy, via Madonna del Piano, I-10-50019Sesto Fiorentino, Italy. Additional authors for this research include Vincenzi Matteo De.
Keywords for this news article include: Institute of BioEconomy, Agriculture, Forestry.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRRY-W4X8-00000-00Prevention or catastrophe: what Chile must do today to face the next wave of forest fires2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisPrevention or catastrophe: what Chile must do today to face the next wave of forest fires


On August 18 was commemorated the "International Day for Forest Fire Prevention", a key date to make visible the global challenge that these environmental catastrophes represent, in a complex current context marked by a hot summer in the northern hemisphere that has facilitated the development of massive fires in countries such as Canada, the United States, Greece and now Spain. A reality that foreshadows a situation not too far away for the summer season in Chile. "The coming season will be very complex, with high temperatures, heat waves and extreme conditions," says Ramón Figueroa, Arauco's assistant manager of Fire Protection. In addition, the forestry company explains, the nature of the fires has also changed. Although almost 99% of them in Chile are of human origin, climate change has intensified their behavior. The seasons have become longer and the events more extreme.


In this context, experts warn of the urgency of facing the crisis with a key strategy that involves collaboration and prevention.
From the National Forestry Corporation (CONAF), Andrés Benedetto, manager of Forest Fire Protection, warns that "the prevention of forest fires in the country must stop being a reactive action and focused on infrastructure, moving from a secondary role to being a structural part of public policies aimed at the environmental, structural and civil protection areas".
Along these lines, he insists that management cannot wait for a catastrophe to occur. "Prevention is the only sustainable strategy in the face of increasingly destructive and frequent forest fires. This implies a profound cultural change, a public policy with a long-term vision and the active commitment of all citizens".
Companies and communities: strategic allies
Despite the role of public sector actors, collaboration with forestry companies and communities is vital, according to experts. Arauco maintains that "the best fire is the one that never happens. Our focus is to protect forests, rural localities and inhabited areas that have historically been affected.
The company has invested in advanced technology, such as 160 360° cameras with artificial intelligence to detect smoke, weather stations, mobile applications for firefighters and a specialized air fleet. But, beyond technology, they highlight community action. "A key contribution from the private sector is the Community Prevention Network (RPC), made up of almost 500 committees in 94 municipalities, of which Arauco supports 327. These are neighbors organized in interface zones, who together with municipalities, electricity companies and the civil protection system help to maintain safety belts, warn of outbreaks and raise awareness among the population".
In this context, CONAF emphasizes that "in all areas, public-private work is essential to advance as a country. Undoubtedly, this takes on an even more transcendental role when it comes to forest fire prevention, mitigation and combat".
The Forest Stewardship Council® (FSC®), which brings together companies, governments, organizations and communities in the protection of forests, provides a concrete vision. Its executive director in Chile, Regina Massai, explains that "FSC certification helps prevent fires because it obliges forestry companies to take a comprehensive look at the territory before working in it. This means assessing possible impacts, identifying risks together with local communities and establishing concrete control and prevention measures".
Like Arauco, the director highlighted the example of RPC. This articulation, promoted by FSC-certified companies, has resulted in "a systematic reduction in fires, which in the last season alone meant a 16% reduction compared to the previous period," explains Massai.
"It is the task of all of us to advance towards a safer and more prepared country in terms of forest fires, including other countries in Latin America and the world, working together towards territorial protection", concludes CONAF.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-KYV3-RWNM-Y072-00000-00Devastating wildfires persist in Portugal: at least four dead and two suspects arrested2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisDevastating wildfires persist in Portugal: at least four dead and two suspects arrested


The forest fire season in Portugal this summer has so far left four fatalities and the arrest of two suspects accused of setting one of the fires.
A new tragedy struck northeastern Portugal on Saturday, when a forestry sapper named Daniel Esteves died as a result of injuries sustained while working to extinguish a fire in the municipality of Sabugal, in the district of Guarda, close to the border with Salamanca and Cáceres.


According to AFP, Esteves, 45 years old and an employee of a private forest protection company, had been burned in 75% of his body by the flames last Tuesday.
Emergency teams managed to stabilize him and transfer him by helicopter to the São João Hospital in Oporto, where he died early Saturday morning. The hospital indicated that the severity of the burns added to pre-existing conditions that complicated his recovery.
The Portuguese Prime Minister, Luís Montenegro, expressed his condolences on his networks and conveyed the gratitude of the whole country to Esteves' family and friends.
President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa also mourned the loss. The institutional reaction was evidence of the national concern in the face of an emergency that constantly challenges civil protection teams.
Esteves joins the other fatalities recorded this summer by forest fires in Portugal: former mayor Carlos Dâmaso, who died in Pêra do Moço on August 15; a firefighter who lost his life in an accident while on his way to the municipality of Fundão; and a 75-year-old man who died trying to put out a fire in Mirandela, Bragança.
The accumulation of these deaths makes this summer one of the toughest in the country's recent forestry history.
Portugal requested the activation of the European Civil Protection Mechanism to receive international reinforcements, after the devastation of almost 234,000 hectares of territory as of August 22, according to official data quoted by Europa Press.
The impact of the fires also extends to neighboring Spain, where fatalities and large territorial losses have been recorded, in a context characterized by heat waves and prolonged drought. According to the European Forest Fire Information System, up to this year Portugal has accumulated an affected area of nearly 278,000 hectares, which reflects the unprecedented magnitude of this emergency.
Two arrested for fire in Coimbra
The Judicial Police arrested on Saturday two men, 20 and 23 years old, suspected of starting a forest fire on August 18 in the area of Lousã, near the mountain range of the same name.
The police indicated that the detainees allegedly used a lighter to light a fire in a rural area with dense vegetation, during a day of maximum risk due to high temperatures and low humidity.
The proximity of homes and the presence of abundant dry vegetation increased the destructive potential of the fire, although firefighters managed to act in time and minimize the damage.
The location and arrest of the suspects was possible thanks to the collaboration of the Working Group for the Reduction of Ignitions in Rural Areas of the Literal Center, composed of the Judicial Police, the Republican National Guard and the Institute for the Conservation of Nature and Forests. The detainees will soon be brought to court.
Very violent" fires in the municipality of Pedrógão Grande
Tension in the Portuguese territory increased this Saturday by the start of two fires described as "very violent" in the municipality of Pedrógão Grande, known for the tragedy of June 2017, when more than 60 people died and hundreds were injured.
The first fire broke out at 14:27 local time in the São Vicente area, mobilizing 247 troops, 57 vehicles and 12 aerial means, given the intensity of the fire and the proximity of inhabited areas. An hour later, another fire broke out in the Graça area, where 105 firefighters, 29 vehicles and a support aircraft were involved.

urn:contentItem:6GR3-JNB3-RS69-F229-00000-00N.L. lifts over month-long provincewide fire ban2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisN.L. lifts over month-long provincewide fire ban

Newfoundland and Labrador has lifted its provincewide fire ban, which had been in effect for more than a month as the result of burning wildfires.

The ban has been in place since Aug. 5 due to extremely dry conditions and multiple wildfires. It was originally set to last until Sept. 7, but was extended due to a wildfire burning near Lethbridge.

Residential fires, including permits to burn grass, brush or other materials, can resume now that the ban has been lifted, but in a statement the provincial government said residents are reminded to take every caution when having a fire to prevent a forest fire from burning.

The entirety of Newfoundland and Labrador is under a low fire risk as of Friday afternoon.

Newfoundland and Labrador's designated wildfire season continues until Sept. 30. A total of 228 wildfires have been reported so far this summer, according to the province's active wildfire dashboard - more than double the 96 reported in 2024.

There are two active wildfires burning in the province at Martin Lake and Kingston, but both are deemed under control.

urn:contentItem:6G00-K603-RS5J-64MW-00000-00North University of China Researchers Further Understanding of Applied Sciences (Evaluation of Thermal Damage Effect of Forest Fire Based on Multispectral Camera Combined with Dual Annealing Algorithm)2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - APPLIED SCIENCESNorth University of China Researchers Further Understanding of Applied Sciences (Evaluation of Thermal Damage Effect of Forest Fire Based on Multispectral Camera Combined with Dual Annealing Algorithm)


2025 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on applied sciences. According to news reporting originating from Taiyuan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "In recent years, the frequency and severity of large-scale forest fires have increased globally, threatening forest ecosystems, human lives, and property while potentially triggering cascading ecological and social crises."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China; State Key Laboratory of Quantum Optics And Quantum Optics Devices; Shanxi Provincial Key Research And Development Project; Central Guided Local Science And Technology Development Funding Program.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from North University of China: "Despite significant advancements in remote sensing-based forest fire monitoring, early warning systems, and fire risk zoning, post-fire thermal damage assessment remains insufficiently addressed. This study introduces an innovative approach combining multispectral imaging with a dual annealing constrained optimization algorithm to enable dynamic monitoring of fire temperature distribution. Based on this method, we develop a dynamic thermal damage assessment model to quantify thermal impacts during forest fires."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The proposed model provides valuable insights for defining thermal damage zones, optimizing evacuation strategies, and supporting firefighting operations, ultimately enhancing emergency response and forest fire management efficiency."
For more information on this research see: Evaluation of Thermal Damage Effect of Forest Fire Based on Multispectral Camera Combined with Dual Annealing Algorithm. Applied Sciences, 2025,15(10):5553. (Applied Sciences - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/applsci). The publisher for Applied Sciences is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/app15105553.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Pan Pei, State Key Laboratory of Extreme Environment Optoelectronic Dynamic Testing Technology and Instrument, North University of China, Taiyuan 030051, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Xiaojian Hao, Ziqi Wu, Rui Jia, Shenxiang Feng, Tong Wei, Wenxiang You, Chenyang Xu, Xining Wang, Yuqian Dong.
Keywords for this news article include: North University of China, Taiyuan, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms, Applied Sciences, Science.

urn:contentItem:6G6T-MWR3-RS5F-X35H-00000-00Researchers at Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School Publish New Data on Physics (FireCLIP: Enhancing Forest Fire Detection with Multimodal Prompt Tuning and Vision-Language Understanding)2025-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisPHYSICSResearchers at Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School Publish New Data on Physics (FireCLIP: Enhancing Forest Fire Detection with Multimodal Prompt Tuning and Vision-Language Understanding)


2025 JUL 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on physics. According to news originating from Shenzhen, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires are a global environmental threat to human life and ecosystems."


Financial supporters for this research include Yunnan Provincial Science And Technology Plan Project; Shenzhen Science And Technology Innovation Commission; Key Field Research And Development Program of Guangdong, China.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School: "This study compiles smoke alarm images from five high-definition surveillance cameras in Foshan City, Guangdong, China, collected over one year, to create a smoke-based early warning dataset. The dataset presents two key challenges: (1) high false positive rates caused by pseudo-smoke interference, including non-fire conditions like cooking smoke and industrial emissions, and (2) significant regional data imbalances, influenced by varying human activity intensities and terrain features, which impair the generalizability of traditional pre-train-fine-tune strategies. To address these challenges, we explore the use of visual language models to differentiate between true alarms and false alarms."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Additionally, our method incorporates a prompt tuning strategy which helps to improve performance by at least 12.45% in zero-shot learning tasks and also enhances performance in few-shot learning tasks, demonstrating enhanced regional generalization compared to baselines."
For more information on this research see: FireCLIP: Enhancing Forest Fire Detection with Multimodal Prompt Tuning and Vision-Language Understanding. Fire, 2025,8(6):237. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8060237.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Shanjunxia Wu, Institute of Safety Science and Technology, Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Shenzhen 518000, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Yuming Qiao, Sen He, Jiahao Zhou, Zhi Wang, Xin Li, Fei Wang.
Keywords for this news article include: Tsinghua Shenzhen International Graduate School, Shenzhen, People's Republic of China, Asia, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6GJH-PGH3-RRJ4-V3F3-00000-00Wildfires in Spain signal growing climate risks for Europe, expert warns2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSWildfires in Spain signal growing climate risks for Europe, expert warnsNeil Stokes,Huang Yan

MADRID, Aug. 21 (Xinhua) -- The devastating wildfires sweeping across Spain this summer should serve as a warning to the rest of Europe about the rising dangers of climate change, a Barcelona-based climatologist said on Wednesday. "This is a warning to countries that have traditionally enjoyed temperate, cool summers... because these conditions of intense heat will increase in latitude and will reach these countries," Javier Martin-Vide, climatologist and professor of physical geography at the University of Barcelona, told Xinhua.

According to Thursday's update from the European Forest Fire Information System, wildfires have scorched 403,171 hectares of land in Spain so far this year. Around 350,000 hectares were destroyed in just the past two weeks, coinciding with a severe heat wave that began in early August. Martin-Vide emphasized that climate models point to worsening conditions in the coming decades. "Adaptation is key to reducing the risk," he said, noting that temperatures exceeding 40 degrees Celsius in central and northern Europe will pose serious challenges to societies less accustomed to extreme heat. He called for stronger prevention measures and better landscape management, highlighting the effects of rural depopulation. "The woods are not as clean as in the past, when there were cattle, sheep, goats grazing and eating the vegetation that now acts as the fuel that starts a forest fire," he explained. The climatologist urged innovative strategies, including the creation of "mosaic landscapes with forest areas interspersed with cultivated fields," to make land more defensible against blazes. He also pointed to adaptation already underway in agriculture, as olive and wine producers move production to higher altitudes, in search of more favorable climatic conditions to maintain both quality and output. Martin-Vide welcomed the Spanish government's plan to establish a nationwide pact on fire prevention, calling it "very necessary." Spain is enduring its worst summer for wildfires this century, with more than 20 major blazes still burning, mainly in the northwestern provinces of Orense, Zamora and Leon. The interior ministry said over 33,000 people have been evacuated, while four people, including three firefighters, have died. Enditem

urn:contentItem:6H04-CSB3-RWN5-C1CY-00000-00HEALTHY NATURE FOR BETTER FOOD SYSTEMS: UN AWARDS NEW WORLD RESTORATION FLAGSHIPS2025-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisHEALTHY NATURE FOR BETTER FOOD SYSTEMS: UN AWARDS NEW WORLD RESTORATION FLAGSHIPSStates News ServiceROME, Italy

The following information was released by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO):

The four newly recognized World Restoration Flagships span 18 countries on four continents

14/10/2025

Rome The United Nations (UN) has named four new World Restoration Flagships under the UN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration. Recognizing global efforts to heal degraded ecosystems, boost community incomes and support food security, the announcement was made during a high-level side event at the World Food Forum in Rome, ahead of World Food Day.

The World Restoration Flagship awards, led by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), spotlight some of the most ambitious and promising large-scale restoration efforts to halt land degradation and ensure healthier, more resilient agrifood systems.

The awards track and celebrate initiatives that contribute to global commitments to restore one billion hectares an area roughly the size of China. In 2022, the inaugural 10 World Restoration Flagships were recognized, followed by seven initiatives in 2024 and three ocean-related initiatives in 2025.

"Restoring ecosystems is not just an environmental imperative it is a cornerstone of global agrifood systems and resilience for the climate, for biodiversity, and for millions of people who depend on healthy ecosystems for foods and livelihoods," said QU Dongyu, Director-General of FAO

The four newly recognized World Restoration Flagships span 18 countries on four continents. They are already restoring more than 500 000 hectares an area nearly five times the size of Rome, where FAO is marking its 80th anniversary this week. By the end of the decade, the initiatives expect to have under restoration almost 500,000 additional hectares of forests, mountains, farmlands, grasslands, shrublands and savannahs, as well as coastal and freshwater ecosystems.

"These flagships show what is doable when people come together to reverse the impacts of climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and waste," said Inger Andersen, Executive Director of UNEP. "As a fierce thunderstorm can end with birdsong, degraded ecosystems can be revived. At scale, these efforts deliver multiple benefits, including food security and livelihoods."

Collaborative Rangelands Restoration Jordan

Tel al-Rumman, north of Amman, is an open mountainous forest area, which had been severely degraded due to illegal overgrazing. When Jordan set out to establish its first botanic garden, instead of unclaimed forest land, ecologists met 4 500 sheep and the communities tending to them.

What could have led to conflict resulted in partnership instead. The Royal Botanic Gardens is now working together with traditional herders on reviving sustainable practices, and 180 hectares are being restored to showcase all of Jordan's unique plants and ecosystems. Biomass production is already growing more than eight-fold, benefiting local herders. Communities can now make use of seven times more grazing days, lower feed costs, and income that more than doubled. The number of herding families has also grown more than 10 times over.

The program's participatory model demonstrates that restoring biodiversity can strengthen food production and community trust, using both scientific methods and traditional knowledge on range practices, livestock management and ecological restoration.

Revitalizing Korea's Forests after Fire Republic of Korea

The Uljin forest fire will be remembered as one of the Republic of Korea's worst ecological disasters, burning through over 20 000 hectares in about ten days.

This World Restoration Flagship in Uljin-gun is restoring the country's valuable forests while prioritising community livelihoods and post-fire resilience. This includes reviving native plant species such as the endangered spike rosebay and the habitat of the long-tailed goral, a small goat-like mammal. The entire fire-damaged area is expected to be restored by 2030.

The Republic of Korea took a unique approach to post-fire restoration, focused on bringing back biodiversity over economically viable tree species, and involving communities along the way. The country is home to one of only two major doomsday seed vaults worldwide. Complementing the Svalbard Global Seed Vault in Norway, which focuses on crop species, the Republic of Korea's Baekdudaegan vault at the Native Plant Seed Supply Center was established in 2023 in response to the forest fire. It saves and researches wild tree and plant seeds, supporting efforts to bounce back from fires.

The Restoration Initiative working across Africa and Asia

This initiative brings together nine countries: Cameroon, China, Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, Guinea Bissau, Kenya, Pakistan, Sao Tome and Principe, and Tanzania. Supported since 2018 by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), FAO, UNEP and the Global Environment Fund (GEF), this initiative aims to overcome barriers to large-scale restoration, sharing know-how on improving awareness, monitoring, supporting businesses, and drawing investments.

The initiative has brought to date over 310 000 hectares under restoration and 717 000 under improved management practices, and it plans to bring under restoration over 160 000 additional hectares by 2030. To date, over 420 000 people have directly benefited from the programme, while mitigating over 30 million tonnes of COa,, equivalent equivalent to emissions from eight coal-fired power plants in one year.

The Restoration Initiative is designed to translate global restoration goals to local contexts for example by boosting local restoration economies, such as nurseries, training smallholder farmers and pastoralists, removing invasive species and informing government policies.

Bamboo-based restoration multiple countries

Across nine countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America, bamboo is being harnessed as a fast-growing, sustainable plant for land restoration, reversing the impacts of intense agriculture, logging, demand for fuelwood and charcoal and climate change.

Bamboo-based restoration supports poverty reduction, creating livelihoods, carbon storage, land degradation and biodiversity loss, including iconic bamboo lemurs, gorillas and the giant panda.

The initiative, led by the International Bamboo and Rattan Organization (INBAR), has already restored about 200 000 hectares and benefited a similar number of people from improved livelihoods and incomes. By 2030, the initiative aims to attract investments to restore an additional 300 000 hectares. This is being achieved through knowledge development and capacity building of governments and local communities. Key enabling factors for this initiative include the harmonization of policies, the participation of multiple sectors in the economy, respecting Indigenous People's rights and cultural considerations, and scientifically choosing appropriate bamboo species out of 1 600 existing species and building appropriate value-chains.

NOTES TO EDITORS

About the UN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration

The UN General Assembly has declared 20212030 aUN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration. Led by the UN Environment Programme and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN, together with the support of partners, it is designed to prevent, halt, and reverse the loss and degradation of ecosystems worldwide. It aims at reviving billions of hectares, covering terrestrial as well as aquatic ecosystems. A global call to action, the UN Decade draws together political support, scientific research, and financial muscle to massively scale up restoration.

About the UN World Restoration Flagships

Countries have already promised to restore1 billion hectares roughly the size of China as part of their commitments to theParis climate agreement, theAichi targetsfor biodiversity, theLand Degradation Neutralitytargets and theBonn Challenge. However, little is known about the progress or quality of this restoration. With the World Restoration Flagships, the UN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration is honouring the best examples of large-scale and long-term ecosystem restoration in any country or region, embodying the 10 Restoration Principles of the UN Decade.Progress of all World Restoration Flagships will be transparently monitored through the Framework for Ecosystem Restoration Monitoring, the UN Decade's platform for keeping track of global restoration efforts.

About the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) UNEPis the leading global voice on the environment. It provides leadership and encourages partnership in caring for the environment by inspiring, informing and enabling nations and peoples to improve their quality of life without compromising that of future generations.

About the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO)

FAOis a specialized agency of the United Nations that leads international efforts to defeat hunger. It aims to achieve food security for all and make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active healthy lives. With over 194 Members, FAO works in over 130 countries worldwide.

urn:contentItem:6GB1-6D43-RX4F-93C5-00000-00Effects of Exposure to Forest Fire Smoke on Respiratory Health in Rural Communities of San Jose de Chiquitos, Bolivia2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisPUBLIC AND GLOBAL HEALTHEffects of Exposure to Forest Fire Smoke on Respiratory Health in Rural Communities of San Jose de Chiquitos, Bolivia


2025 JUL 22 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- According to news reporting based on a preprint abstract, our journalists obtained the following quote sourced from medrxiv.org:


“Forest fires in Bolivia have increased in frequency and intensity, posing environmental and human health threats.
“This study evaluated the impact of air pollution from forest fires on the health of San Jose de Chiquitos, Santa Cruz, Bolivia9s population.
“A cross-sectional study was conducted in two affected communities (Los Ciros and Pororo), collecting epidemiological and environmental data in September 2024. The results show that the symptoms most reported by the population exposed to smoke were respiratory (difficulty breathing in 71.4% of cases), followed by irritation in mucous membranes (77.1%), throat (80.0%), and eyes (85.7%). Although no significant differences were observed in all conditions, Los Ciros had a higher prevalence of symptoms, suggesting that poorer baseline health status could aggravate the effects of smoke. The most frequent mitigation measures were the use of masks (63.6%), staying indoors (54.5%), and the use of wet cloths (21.2%), without finding a significant association between these strategies and the reduction of symptoms.
“This study highlights the need to improve air pollution protection strategies in communities affected by wildfires and develop prevention policies to mitigate their effects on public health.”
This preprint has not been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2025.07.06.25327500v1
Keywords for this news article include: Air Pollution, Epidemiology, Public and Global Health.
