urn:contentItem:6H1V-54N3-S10X-P1F3-00000-00GOVERNMENT OF CANADA RECOGNIZES 11 NEW DESIGNATIONS OF NATIONAL HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCE2025-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisGOVERNMENT OF CANADA RECOGNIZES 11 NEW DESIGNATIONS OF NATIONAL HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCEStates News ServiceGATINEAU, Quebec

The following information was released by the Government of Canada:

Today, the Honourable Steven Guilbeault, Minister of Canadian Identity and Culture and Minister responsible for Official Languages, announced 11 designations of persons, places and events of national historic significance under Parks Canada's National Program of Historical Commemoration. These designations honour the diversity of history in Canada. These include:

Places:Seven Oaks House in Winnipeg, Manitoba

Persons: William Kennedy, Charlotte Edith Anderson Monture, Mary Two-Axe Earley, Everett Baker

Events: RCMP Musical Ride, Invention of the Morris Rod-Weeder, Rural Electrification Across Canada, Klippert Case, 1967, Miramichi Fire of 1825, First World War Training at Sarcee Camp

Some highlights from today's announcement include:

Rural Electrification Across Canada: In the early 20th century, most Canadians lived in rural areas without electricity. Advocacy from women's and farmers' groups helped drive a national push for rural electrification, promoted heavily by utility companies as a modern necessity. Each province took a different approachfrom Ontario's publicly owned system to Alberta's cooperatives and Saskatchewan's rapid expansion with farmers. While electrification reshaped rural Canada, some rural residents resisted change, and many First Nations were left out. By the 1970s, nearly all rural households across Canada were connected to central power stations, dramatically improving quality of life and enabling new technologies.

Mary Two-Axe Earley: This Kanien'keha:ka (Mohawk) woman was a trailblazer in the fight for equality for First Nations women. She brought national attention to the gender discrimination in the Indian Act, which stripped women of their Indian status if they married non-status men. Her advocacy led to changes in the law in 1985, allowing women to retain and pass on their status to their children. Two-Axe Earley was the first person to have her status reinstated under the amended Indian Act.

RCMP Musical Ride: With origins in British cavalry traditions, this grand precision performance of scarlet-uniformed police constables on horseback, coordinated with music, was first performed in Regina, North-West Territories (now Saskatchewan), in 1887. The Musical Ride demonstrates the longstanding importance of horsemanship in the history of the federal police force. In 1961, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police created an annual Ride, performing more than one hundred times per year by 1966. Since 1988, officers selected for the Ride serve a three-year term before returning to regular police duties. The Ride now tours across Canada and around the world from May to October.

Miramichi Fire: In October 1825, the Miramichi Fire burned an estimated 15,500 km2 in northeastern New Brunswick, devastating communities, killing hundreds of people, and leaving thousands more homeless. Roughly 50,000 was raised to help the entire colony, and this is thought to have been the largest disaster relief effort in pre-Confederation Canadian history. The relief effort strengthened ties between the colony of New Brunswick and Great Britain, the United States, and the colonies of Upper and Lower Canada. This massive forest fire had extensive environmental impacts in New Brunswick, and lasting changes to the ecosystem had an impact on settlers and Mi'kmaq whose lives and livelihoods depended on the lands and waters of the Miramichi region. In the aftermath of the fire, timber exploitation moved to new frontiers while the Miramichi region's industry shifted to the processed lumber trade.

First World War Training at Sarcee Camp: In 1915, reflecting Canada's commitment to the First World War, the government established Sarcee Camp near Calgary on lands recently surrendered by the Tsuut'ina (Sarcee) First Nation. As one of Canada's largest training camps, it introduced over 45,000 Canadians to military life before they were sent overseas. Stone markers on Signal Hill commemorate the thousands who trained there. The camp's creation highlights the pressures faced by First Nations when lands promised for their exclusive use were repurposed for military needs, sparking ongoing conflict. For the Tsuut'ina Nation, the extensive military use of these lands in the 20th century remains a significant legacy. Sarcee Camp's continued use during the Second World War and the Cold War underscores its lasting role in Canada's military history.

The Government of Canada, through the recommendations from the Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada and Parks Canada, recognizes significant persons, places, and events that have shaped our country as one way of helping Canadians connect with their past. By sharing these stories with Canadians, we hope to foster understanding and reflection on the diverse histories, cultures, legacies, and realities of Canada's past and present.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV33-RXJ5-81HN-00000-00Alert in Arequipa: Indeci warns of possible explosions of Sabancaya volcano that could affect Colca districts and nearby areas2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisAlert in Arequipa: Indeci warns of possible explosions of Sabancaya volcano that could affect Colca districts and nearby areas

Alert in Arequipa: Indeci warns of possible explosions of Sabancaya volcano that could affect districts of Colca and nearby areasIndeci warned that Sabancaya volcano explosions could cause eruptive columns of more than 2 km high and issued recommendations to the population.

Camila Salinas Tipiani
The National Institute of Civil Defense (Indeci) informed that the Sabancaya volcano registered a sudden and significant increase in eruptive activity and, therefore, raised the volcanic alert level to orange. It also warned of the possible occurrence of explosions that could generate eruptive columns higher than 2 km and that this would affect districts located in the Colca valley and nearby areas of Arequipa.


In addition, it reported that on September 13 an explosion occurred that caused an "eruptive column higher than 5 km over the summit of the volcano, accompanied by pyroclastic flows". In this regard, the Peruvian Geophysical Institute (IGP) stated that the recorded event "represents an increase in volcanic activity that increases the probability of new explosions in the short and medium term".
WE RECOMMEND YOUCurwen in La Republica : Phillip Butters vs. Curwen's revenge Indeci on possible Sabancaya volcano explosions
Indeci exposed that the Sabancaya volcano explosions would damage the Colca volcano districts and surrounding areas through the dispersion of volcanic ash, according to IGP information. For its part, the IGP reported that the staff of the National Volcanological Center (Cenvul) went to the crater, climbed over 5960 m. a. s. n. m. and was able to monitor, and alert about possible volcanic eruptions of Sabancaya, which has been erupting since 2016
"The alert level is orange, due to the volcano significantly increasing its eruptive activity. Increased seismic activity, frequent occurrence of explosions and the emission of ashes and ballistic blocks are observed", indicated Cenvul.
Recommendations of the IGP before volcanic alert

Implement prevention measures according to the current orange volcanic alert level.

Do not go within a radius of 12 km from the crater. In case of ash fall, cover nose and mouth with wet cloths or masks. Keep doors and windows of homes closed.

Keep informed about the volcanic activity of Sabancaya through the data provided by the IGP through its website.

Indeci after forest fire in Misti foothills
A forest fire was registered on the afternoon of September 13 in Arequipa; however, the fire intensified during the night. Indeci issued an emergency alert in the districts of Chiguata, Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and Alto Selva Alegre, and urged citizens to stay away from the affected areas while control works continue.
According to initial reports, the fire started around 3:50 p.m. in the pastures located on the slopes of the Misti volcano. So far, the authorities have not reported any loss of life or material damage. It should be noted that the Regional Government of Arequipa and local municipalities coordinated actions with firefighters, National Police personnel, serenazgo and the National Forest and Wildlife Service (Serfor) to contain the emergency.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2D53-RRPK-93HY-00000-00More than half of the fires in Spain in 2024 were caused by negligence and accidents2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisMore than half of the fires in Spain in 2024 were caused by negligence and accidents


The year 2024 ended with 6,150 forest fires, with an affected area of 47,174 hectares in total. This is established in the latest Annual Report of the State Attorney General's Office, which has put the number of people who were arrested or investigated for fire-related incidents at 306.


If we compare this with the total number of people arrested and investigated so far this summer for these causes, 169 (42 arrested and 127 investigated) according to the data of the Ministry of the Interior updated on August 22, the number is much lower than in 2024. On the other hand, most of the accidents for which police interventions took place, according to this report, were not of intentional origin.
On the contrary, according to the data provided monthly by the different police forces to the Prosecutor of the Environmental and Urban Planning Coordinating Chamber of the State Attorney General's Office, most of them were caused by negligence or accidents: More than 50.98% of the fires were caused by this cause compared to 24.18% that were indeed arson, a trend that is maintained in the previous four years. In 2023, 68% of the fires were accidental and 24.18% were arson, while in 2022, 63.50% were accidents and 25.50% were caused voluntarily.
The Public Prosecutor's Office establishes five types of casuistry attributable to the origin of these fires. The so-called "natural" ones, that is to say, not linked in any case to human action, those originated by negligence or accidents (those caused involuntarily by human activity due to carelessness, imprudence or fortuitous situations) or of intentional origin, whose purpose is to produce the forest fire. They can also be caused by "reproductions", that is, when the fire is originated from a previous fire. Finally, we would find all those fires that have not been investigated or where the investigation has not been resolved.
Another revealing fact of the report is that the number of large forest fires (GIF), i.e., all those exceeding 500 ha, was very small compared to small or intermediate sized fires.
Those fires in which police intervention was carried out were 37.5% of the fires that were started and a majority, 61.81%, were fires of between 1 ha and 500 ha. A minimal percentage of these fires corresponded to GIF, only 0.69%.
In other words, the change observed between previous years and this one is the significant increase in the virulence of the fires, which are spreading more and more rapidly and are devastating a larger area. This 2025, more than 411,315 hectares have burned in the worst wave of fires recorded in Spain this century, according to the latest update of the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
This figure is almost 10 times that of 2024. The area burned by fire in 2025 far exceeds the 42,615 hectares burned in 2024, with 219 fires, with an increase in Large Forest Fires (LFF). All this is due, according to experts, not only to the acceleration of the climate crisis, but also to factors such as rural abandonment and different changes in land use, which contribute to the spread of fire.
In relation to previous years, highlights the report of the Prosecutor's Office, the GIFs decreased with respect to the average of the last five years, figures that were at 22 GIFs, being able to highlight a variation of -22.7% in large forest fires.

urn:contentItem:6GRP-KSS3-RTCX-X3F9-00000-00Eco Task Force plants over 6 million saplings in Himachal2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisEco Task Force plants over 6 million saplings in HimachalNew Delhi


September 15 -- 

The 133 Eco Task Force, dedicated to environmental protection in Himachal Pradesh, has emerged as a major force in conservation and afforestation. Since its inception, the unit has planted more than 6.076 million saplings, covering 5,675 hectares across the state. It has also developed 11 nurseries with a combined capacity of 430,000 plants, while rejuvenating three Amrit Sarovars and several ponds.



Over the past 19 years, the force has made remarkable strides not only in afforestation but also in soil conservation, disaster management, and protection of natural resources. According to Col. Deepak Kumar, Commanding Officer of the 133 Eco Task Force, the unit operates on a unique model that engages ex-servicemen. Re-inducted into service as part of a small Army Corps Group, they are entrusted with crucial environmental responsibilities.

In the last five years alone, the Eco Task Force has successfully controlled 43 forest fire incidents and enhanced fire prevention through fire lines in 42 project areas. To further aid water conservation, it has built 11 check dams using locally available materials.

The unit organises special plantation drives during significant events such as Van Mahotsav, Ek Ped Maa Ke Naam, Meri Maati Mera Desh, Swachhata Hi Seva and International Yoga Day. Alongside plantation, its ongoing efforts include safeguarding flora and fauna, preserving water resources and promoting soil stability.

Beyond conservation, the Eco Task Force has also provided shelter, food, and transport to people affected by natural disasters—strengthening its dual commitment to environmental protection and humanitarian service.

urn:contentItem:6GS5-1M33-RWH7-D410-00000-00Spain sweltered under hottest summer on record in 20252025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisSpain sweltered under hottest summer on record in 2025Naharnet Newsdesk

Spain said that summer 2025 was the hottest on record for the southern European nation, which like the entire Mediterranean region is being hard hit by climate change.

Its national weather service said that the country had an average temperature of 24.2 C (75.5 F) between June 1 and Aug. 31. That is the highest temperature since the service started keeping records in 1961. The previous record was set in 2022 at 24.1 C.

This summer was also 2.1 degrees Celsius (3.7 F) hotter than the national average from 1991-2020.

The highest single-day temperature of 45.8 C (119.3 F) was recorded in Jerez de la Frontera, in southern Spain, on Aug. 17 during a heat wave.

The Mediterranean region is heating up 20% faster than the global average, according to the United Nations.

The scorching summer months also saw Spain's countryside burn.

A record 382,000 hectares (944,000 acres) burned in a spate of wildfires, surpassing the previous high of 306,000 hectares (756,000 acres) burned in 2022, according to data compiled by the European Union's European Forest Fire Information System.

Spain's weather service added that the country also had a particularly dry summer, especially in the areas of the northwest where wildfires did most of their damage.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service.

Scientists warn that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness, especially in parts of southern Europe, making the region more vulnerable to health impacts and wildfires.

The main driver of climate change is the burning of fossil fuels like gasoline, oil and coal.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DF3-S547-K02P-00000-00The bottom line on fires: six graphs to understand a fatal 20252025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisThe bottom line on fires: six graphs to understand a fatal 2025


When the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, declared the wave of fires over, she referred to them as a "tragic episode in the history of our country". It has not been another summer of fires in Spain, but the worst of the century, according to EFFIS (European Forest Fire Information System) satellite predictions of all fires of 30 hectares or more. The first estimates exceeded 400,000 hectares, while this week's figures are somewhat lower. Although the methodology differs from the Forest Fire Statistics (EGIF), the one consolidated from the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, the dimensions of these fires have already left a fatal record in history.


Taking only the EFFIS data, this statistical footprint leaves the previous numbers far behind. The 62 large fires (those with more than 500 ha) are only two fewer than the entire year 2022, but six of them have exceeded 20,000 ha. In 2022 and 2021, the only years of the decade with fires of such size, do not reach such a count.
If these figures are already surprising at the national level, how much more so for the regions where these fires have raged. In Ourense some 140,000 hectares have been burned and in León some 70,000, followed by 47,000 in Zamora and 38,000 in Cáceres, according to the latest data under review. The area burned in León and Ourense is, in fact, more than half of the area burned in the last decade (and a quarter in Zamora and Cáceres). Only the lands of Zamora experienced a worse episode in 2022 with the fires in the Sierra de la Culebra.
Fires with their own name
A Rúa, Uña, Chandrexa... There have been so many mega-fires in 2025 that there are many names engraved in the memory of the areas they affected. These fires alone have broken the ceiling of the statistics, without the need to add them up to show the contrast with previous years. Pending uniform data from the Ministry, for the moment they exceed the worst EGIF losses.
The most devastating fires occurred from August 8 to 13. They have made this period the worst since records have been kept, if we take as a reference the total area destroyed by these fires on their day of origin. Thus, the moving average of the weekly hectares at four weeks (almost the equivalent of a month) reveals a much more damaged Spain in this August than in previous EFFIS August.
Again, one must take into account the lag of the EGIF figures, which in principle places its worst peaks well below the 2025 record. But 2025 also ranks well above the peaks of the EFFIS statistical series, such as 2022, the next most prominent year in these satellite records. To put this in context, the A Rúa fire in 2025 is equivalent to the total burned area given by EFFIS for all of 2024.

urn:contentItem:6FT9-78V3-RRW6-41MH-00000-00Findings from Forest Research Institute Provide New Insights into Physics (A Prototype Forest Fire Decision Support System for Uttarakhand, India)2025-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisPHYSICSFindings from Forest Research Institute Provide New Insights into Physics (A Prototype Forest Fire Decision Support System for Uttarakhand, India)


2025 MAY 14 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Fresh data on physics are presented in a new report. According to news originating from Uttarakhand, India, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "We present a study that addresses the critical need for a prototype Decision Support System for forest fire information and management in Uttarakhand, India."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Forest Research Institute: "The study's main objective was to carry out statistical analysis of large fire incident datasets to understand trends of fires in the region and develop essential spatial decision support tools. These tools address the necessary fire management decision-making along with comprehensive datasets that can enable a decision maker to exercise better management. Moreover, this DSS addresses three major components of forest fire decision support: (i) pre-fire (forest information visualization) tools, (ii) during-fire terrain-based spatial decision support tools, and (iii) post-fire restoration tools. The efforts to develop this DSS included satellite lidar dataset-based fuel load estimations, the Keetch-Byram Drought Index, and the integration of spatial tools that ensure better spatial decisions in fire suppression planning. In addition, based on the bibliographic literature, the study also uses ecological and community-based knowledge, including financial aspects, for fire prevention and post-fire restoration planning. The development of this DSS involves an open-source R Shiny framework, enabling any decision maker at the execution or planning level to access these key datasets and simulate the spatial solutions cost-effectively."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Hence, this study aimed to internalize key decision support tools and datasets based on extensive statistical analysis for data-driven forest fire planning and management."
For more information on this research see: A Prototype Forest Fire Decision Support System for Uttarakhand, India. Fire, 2025,8(4):149. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8040149.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Neelesh Yadav, Bioinformatics Center, Forest Research Institute, Dehradun 248006, Uttarakhand, India. Additional authors for this research include Shrey Rakholia, Peter Moore, Laura Patricia Ponce-Calderon, Mithun Kumar S R, Reuven Yosef.
Keywords for this news article include: Forest Research Institute, Uttarakhand, India, Asia, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RS1P-J09W-00000-00The UN statement immediately provoked Israel's anger.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisThe UN statement immediately provoked Israel's anger.


Portugal continues to battle raging forest fires in the center of the country on Friday that have already left three dead and consumed some 60,000 hectares, despite a drop in temperatures that has improved the situation, according to Civil Protection.


Some 1,600 firefighters are battling the blaze, supported by air tankers and helicopters, in what one expert called the largest forest fire ever recorded in the country's history, in the town of Argenil (center).
"It could probably be (...) the largest fire ever recorded in Portugal," said Paulo Fernandes, a professor at the Forestry Sciences department of the University of Tras-Os-Montes, referring to the blaze that started a dozen days ago.}
Temperatures
Portugal, like neighboring Spain, also affected by historic fires this summer, has been experiencing relief on the front lines since Thursday, thanks to a drop in temperatures that should continue over the next few days.
The forest fires have already left three dead and several seriously injured, mostly firefighters, as well as destroying homes and agricultural land.
Prime Minister Luis Montenegro, criticized for his handling of the catastrophe, defended himself from reproaches on Thursday night and said that "only those who do not know the country (...) can think that it is possible to be everywhere, at all times, and anticipate the appearance and rapid spread of all the fires".
At the end of an extraordinary council of ministers, he announced a series of emergency measures in favor of the affected populations, including the financing of housing reconstruction and aid for farmers.
Protection
The head of government also recognized the need to initiate a reflection on forest management and the current civil protection system.
According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), about 276,000 hectares of land have burned since the beginning of the year in Portugal. In 2017, more than 563,000 hectares were burned in fires that resulted in 119 deaths.
The Iberian Peninsula is heavily affected by climate change, which causes heat waves and droughts favorable for forest fires, according to experts.

urn:contentItem:6GRX-KBK3-RWRV-F372-00000-00Spain sweltered under hottest summer on record in 2025, weather agency says2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSINTERNATIONAL NEWSSpain sweltered under hottest summer on record in 2025, weather agency saysMADRID

MADRID (AP) — Spain said Tuesday that summer 2025 was the hottest on record for the southern European nation, which like the entire Mediterranean region is being hard hit by climate change.

Its national weather service said that the country had an average temperature of 24.2 C (75.5 F) between June 1 and Aug. 31. That is the highest temperature since the service started keeping records in 1961. The previous record was set in 2022 at 24.1 C.

This summer was also 2.1 degrees Celsius (3.7 F) hotter than the national average from 1991-2020.

The highest single-day temperature of 45.8 C (119.3 F) was recorded in Jerez de la Frontera, in southern Spain, on Aug. 17 during a heat wave.

The Mediterranean region is heating up 20% faster than the global average, according to the United Nations.

The scorching summer months also saw Spain's countryside burn.

A record 382,000 hectares (944,000 acres) burned in a spate of wildfires, surpassing the previous high of 306,000 hectares (756,000 acres) burned in 2022, according to data compiled by the European Union’s European Forest Fire Information System.

Spain's weather service added that the country also had a particularly dry summer, especially in the areas of the northwest where wildfires did most of their damage.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service.

Scientists warn that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness, especially in parts of southern Europe, making the region more vulnerable to health impacts and wildfires.

The main driver of climate change is the burning of fossil fuels like gasoline, oil and coal.

urn:contentItem:6GVR-65R3-RTGH-300B-00000-00Xiangtan University Researchers Provide New Study Findings on Mathematics (UAV Path Planning for Forest Firefighting Using Optimized Multi-Objective Jellyfish Search Algorithm)2025-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisMATHEMATICSXiangtan University Researchers Provide New Study Findings on Mathematics (UAV Path Planning for Forest Firefighting Using Optimized Multi-Objective Jellyfish Search Algorithm)


2025 SEP 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in mathematics. According to news originating from Xiangtan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "This paper presents a novel approach to address the challenges of complex terrain, dynamic wind fields, and multi-objective constraints in multi-UAV collaborative path planning for forest firefighting missions."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Xiangtan University: "An extensible algorithm, termed Parallel Vectorized Differential Evolution-based Multi-Objective Jellyfish Search (PVDE-MOJS), is proposed to enhance path planning performance. A comprehensive multi-objective cost function is formulated, incorporating path length, threat avoidance, altitude constraints, path smoothness, and wind effects. Forest-specific constraints are modeled using cylindrical threat zones and segmented wind fields. The conventional jellyfish search algorithm is then enhanced through multi-core parallel fitness evaluation, vectorized non-dominated sorting, and differential evolution-based mutation. These improvements substantially boost convergence efficiency and solution quality in high-dimensional optimization scenarios. Simulation results on the Phillip Archipelago Forest Farm digital elevation model (DEM) in Australia demonstrate that PVDE-MOJS outperforms the original MOJS algorithm in terms of inverted generational distance (IGD) across benchmark functions UF1-UF10."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The proposed method achieves effective obstacle avoidance, altitude optimization, and wind adaptation, producing uniformly distributed Pareto fronts. This work offers a viable solution for emergency UAV path planning in forest fire rescue scenarios, with future extensions aimed at dynamic environments and large-scale UAV swarms."
For more information on this research see: UAV Path Planning for Forest Firefighting Using Optimized Multi-Objective Jellyfish Search Algorithm. Mathematics, 2025,13(17):2745. (Mathematics - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/mathematics). The publisher for Mathematics is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/math13172745.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Rui Zeng, School of Computer Science and School of Cyberspace Science, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Runteng Luo, Bin Liu.

July 16th, 2025 (Idaho Capital Sun — Delivered by Newstex)

The Idaho Board of Land Commissioners meets July 15 at the Idaho State Capitol in Boise. (Photo by Clark Corbin/Idaho Capital Sun)

Idaho Department of Lands officials are considering proposing a bill during the 2026 legislative session that would increase the fire protection surcharge for lots with residential structures on forest lands to pay for fire protection programs.

Idaho Department of Lands Deputy Director Bill Haagenson briefed Gov. Brad Little and members of the Idaho Board of Land Commissioners on the proposed bill during a meeting Tuesday at the Idaho State Capitol in Boise.

Idaho wildfire potential remains high as hot temperatures continue

#8216;Idaho wildfire potential remains high as hot temperatures continue #8217; — Idaho Capital Sun

Under current state law, the owners of forest lands with residential structures pay a $40 annual surcharge for fire protection, which has not increased since 2009. The new proposal would allow the state to increase the surcharge, not to exceed $100 for each improved lot or parcel to offset the cost of fire preparedness.

Haagenson told Little and the Land Board that the current $40 annual surcharge is not enough to support the state's fire protection program, particularly as Idaho continues to grow and more homes are built in areas where human development and forest lands meet.

#8216;The proposal is to change the improved particle surcharge from $40 to up to $100 and that change is needed to ensure funding for the future of healthy wildfire protection,#8217; Haggenson said.

About 67,000 parcels of land in forests in Idaho are subject to the surcharge, Haagenson said. If the state raised the surcharge to $100, that would generate about $4 million more per year in funding for wildfires, state officials said.

Little and Land Board members voted to approve the proposal, with the potential for Idaho Department of Lands officials to make further revisions or withdraw it entirely. That means the department can move forward with the proposal but may change it or decide not to bring it forward.

For the change to take effect, the proposal would need to be introduced as a bill during an upcoming session of the Idaho Legislature, receive a majority of votes in both the Idaho Senate and Idaho House of Representatives and be signed into law by the governor.

The 2026 legislative session is scheduled to begin Jan. 12 in Boise.

urn:contentItem:6FX8-TBR3-RVCG-33V4-00000-00Recent Findings from Beijing Forestry University Has Provided New Information about Artificial Intelligence (Advancements In Artificial Intelligence Applications for Forest Fire Prediction)2025-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:36ZLexisNexisARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCERecent Findings from Beijing Forestry University Has Provided New Information about Artificial Intelligence (Advancements In Artificial Intelligence Applications for Forest Fire Prediction)


2025 MAY 28 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in Artificial Intelligence. According to news originating from Beijing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "In recent years, the increasingly significant impacts of climate change and human activities on the environment have led to more frequent occurrences of extreme events such as forest fires. The recurrent wildfires pose severe threats to ecological environments and human life safety."


Funders for this research include National Key R&D Program of China, National Natural Science Foundation of China.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Beijing Forestry University, "Consequently, forest fire prediction has become a current research hotspot, where accurate forecasting technologies are crucial for reducing ecological and economic losses, improving forest fire management efficiency, and ensuring personnel safety and property security. To enhance comprehensive understanding of wildfire prediction research, this paper systematically reviews studies since 2015, focusing on two key aspects: datasets with related tools and prediction algorithms. We categorized the literature into three categories: statistical analysis and physical models, traditional machine learning methods, and deep learning approaches. Additionally, this review summarizes the data types and open-source datasets used in the selected literature. The paper further outlines current challenges and future directions, including exploring wildfire risk data management and multimodal deep learning, investigating self-supervised learning models, improving model interpretability and developing explainable models, integrating physics-informed models with machine learning, and constructing digital twin technology for real-time wildfire simulation and fire scenario analysis."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This study aims to provide valuable support for forest natural resource management and enhanced environmental protection through the application of remote sensing technologies and artificial intelligence algorithms."
For more information on this research see: Advancements In Artificial Intelligence Applications for Forest Fire Prediction. Forests, 2025;16(4):704. Forests can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Pengle Cheng, Beijing Forestry University, School of Technology, Beijing 100083, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Hui Liu, Lifu Shu, Mingyu Wang, Xiaodong Liu and Ying Huang.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/f16040704. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Beijing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Artificial Intelligence, Cyborgs, Ecology, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning, Technology, Beijing Forestry University.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y603-RRXK-G51P-00000-00A fire forces the high-speed train between Madrid and Andalusia to be interrupted for almost an hour.2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisA fire forces the high-speed train between Madrid and Andalusia to be interrupted for almost an hour.


A fire has forced this Tuesday to cut rail traffic between Brazatortas and Venta la Inés (Ciudad Real), affecting long-distance and high-speed trains on the Madrid-Andalusia line .


In a publication in its social networks, Adif assured that the fire was outside the railway operation and that the circulation in that section was suspended from 16.35 hours. For its part, Renfe said that the cut had occurred at the request of firefighters since the fire was close to the track.
An hour later, both have reported that the stopped trains resumed the march "progressively" after the fire was extinguished. "Circulation is tending to normalize," said Adif.
The forest fire information system of Castilla-La Mancha detailed on its website that fourteen troops worked on extinguishing a fire in the town of Brazatortas from 16.07 hours.
Likewise, Adif also informed that the Guardia Civil had asked to interrupt the circulation between Talavera de la Reina and Montearagón, on the Madrid-Extremadura line, due to an obstacle near the tracks. Almost an hour later, he confirmed that the obstacle had been removed and circulation was restored.
A fire has forced this Tuesday to cut the railway circulation between Brazatortas and Venta la Inés (Ciudad Real), affecting long-distance and high-speed trains on the Madrid-Andalusia line .

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S873-RXN7-S22N-00000-00Misti fire: Fire destroyed habitat of more than 50 species of flora and fauna (PHOTOS)2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisMisti fire: Fire destroyed habitat of more than 50 species of flora and fauna (PHOTOS)


The forest fire that started on September 13 on the slopes of the Misti volcano devastated a high Andean ecosystem of scrub and grassland, affecting at least 50 species of flora. According to the National Forestry and Wildlife Service (SERFOR), 15 of them are categorized as vulnerable and eight are endemic to the region, such as the cahuato (Tecoma arequipensis).


Regarding the fauna, Luis Felipe Gonzáles Dueñas, Technical Forestry and Wildlife Administrator in Arequipa, indicated that the exact number of species affected has not yet been determined, but traces of Andean foxes, partridges, lizards, and wild guinea pig shelters have been identified, in addition to birds whose nests were consumed by the fire.
Fortunately, no injured specimens have been found during the intervention, but the loss of habitat seriously compromises the survival of these species in the area.
The official explained that the recovery of the area will depend on rainfall, as the ecosystem is adapted to long periods of drought. "If permanent rainfall is recorded, regeneration could take between three and four years. The grasslands will grow first, but the shrub species will take longer to recover," he said.
Gonzáles Dueñas warned that the fire is suspected to have been caused by alleged invaders who were marking out land in the area. For this reason, the agency announced that it will initiate investigations and apply administrative sanctions against those responsible, which could be up to 10 UITs.
For the moment, SERFOR has not yet specified the exact extent of the hectares consumed, as the official estimate is made after analyzing the "fire scar" using satellite images and technical reports.

urn:contentItem:6GCH-0R03-S3TJ-S142-00000-00Study Results from United Arab Emirates University Update Understanding of Information Technology (Documentation of Historical Forest Fires and Hazard: Case of Gironde and Les Landes, France)2025-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisINFORMATION TECHNOLOGYStudy Results from United Arab Emirates University Update Understanding of Information Technology (Documentation of Historical Forest Fires and Hazard: Case of Gironde and Les Landes, France)


2025 JUL 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Research findings on information technology are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Al Ain, United Arab Emirates, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fire is becoming an important research topic because of climate change and its impact on population. In this study, historical database about forest fire incidents was created for Gironde and Les Landes (1989 to 2022)."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from United Arab Emirates University: "To the knowledge of the authors, this database did not exist before. The database is essential in showing spatial and temporal distribution of forest fires and helps in decision-making. The database was created from newspapers and crosschecked with burned areas visible on Landsat and Sentinel-2 satellite images. Several factors were used to generate a forest fire hazard map such as vegetation water content utilizing Normalized Difference Moisture Index (NDMI), type of vegetation, topography, and barriers to the expansion of fire (proximity to water bodies and roads). All layers were converted to raster format and reclassified to a common scale. Weighted overlay in GIS was used to generate the final forest fire hazard map. Results showed that, temporally most forest fires occurred during March-April and July-August and majority are in Gironde. The hazard map highlights that most of Les Landes and Gironde departments are vulnerable to this hazard because of their extended forest areas and high dryness. The accuracy assessment showed that supervised classification had the best accuracy followed by the Burned Area Detection Index (BADI) and the manual digitization."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Data from French institutions and higher-resolution satellite images could improve the accuracy of the historical forest fires database. The output from the study was made available to the public for further exploration ( https://firemap.saro.app/ )."
For more information on this research see: Documentation of Historical Forest Fires and Hazard: Case of Gironde and Les Landes, France. ISPRS Annals of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 2025,X-G-2025():771-778. (ISPRS Annals of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - http://www.isprs.org/publications/annals.aspx). urn:contentItem:6G1X-5PC3-RRJY-72M9-00000-00Wildfire burning in Wharton State Forest, New Jersey Forest Fire Service says2025-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisWildfire burning in Wharton State Forest, New Jersey Forest Fire Service saysBy Frederick Sutton Sinclair, Ryan Hughes(KYW)

Click here for updates on this story

New Jersey (KYW) -- A wildfire is burning in the area of the Emilio Carranza Memorial in the Wharton State Forest in Shamong Township, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service and Department of Environmental Protection said.

As of 2:15 p.m., Saturday, the wildfire had grown to 5,000 acres and was 60% contained, NJFFS said.

"The fire has got some serious burning going on right now and with that, we're having a hard time to control it," said NJFFS Chief Bill Donnelly during a press conference Friday night.

The smoke was having impacts on air quality around Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware on Friday night and into Saturday morning.

Donnelly said Friday night that roughly 150 firefighters are fighting the wildfire, which has been named the Mines Spung Wildfire. Additionally, 25 fire trucks/brush trucks, 25 fire engines from local departments are assisting with the firefight, the NJFFS chief said.

The fire was first reported by a private aircraft flying over the area around 5 a.m. Friday. Officials said the dry, sandy soil has fueled the flames.

"The main challenge is we're in a very remote area, Wharton State Forest, so limited access," NJFFS assistant firewarden David Achey said. "No cellphone service communications have been a little bit of an issue, but we're working on straightening that kind of stuff out. So, just the remoteness of the location and the fuels we're dealing with. This is the heart of the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, so very violate fuels."

Local forest roads, as well as Tuckerton Road from Carranza Road to Washington Turnpike, Carranza Road from Forked Neck Road to Tuckerton Road, Bulldozer and Hampton roads, are closed as firefighters continue to battle the wildfire. The Batona Trail is also closed between Carranza and Quaker Bridge roads.

The Lower Forge Campground and Phillip M. Costello Preparatory Academy were evacuated on Friday as a precaution, according to the NJFFS. Donnelly previously said around 23 students were evacuated from the school, but officials anticipate they'll be allowed back in as soon as possible.

Five homes near the fire were told to shelter in place, Donnelly said. No injuries have been reported at this time.

However, Brittney Poulysyn, who lives down the street on Carranza Road, said she's been keeping tabs on the fire.

"I saw smoke down this way, down Forked Neck Road, I saw smoke," she said while pointing down the road. "I keep track of it on the PulsePoint app, and we have the local Facebook group pages."

The cause of the fire is under investigation.

Jessica MacAulay and Nate Sylves contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:6GR1-WSH3-RRSM-611D-00000-00Conservation of indigenous lands in the Amazon reduces disease, study shows2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisConservation of indigenous lands in the Amazon reduces disease, study shows


Indigenous lands (ILs) are essential for preserving biodiversity, especially in tropical regions, but their contributions to human health are still poorly understood. To fill this gap, researchers from the countries of the Amazon basin are carrying out an unprecedented study focused on the benefits related to the territories occupied by indigenous peoples.


This research, funded by the Ford Foundation, brought together researchers from eight countries in the Amazon basin, with Brazil playing a leading role, as it holds the largest portion of the forest (around 60% of the total). The study also includes information from Colombia, Bolivia, Peru, French Guiana, Venezuela, Suriname and Ecuador - the only country missing was Guyana.
The work was published on Thursday (11) in the scientific journal Communications Earth & Environment, from the Nature group.
"The focus was initially only on the Brazilian Amazon and fire-related diseases. And then we extended it to a second phase to understand if the effects were maintained when we looked at the entire biome and other aspects of human health," Paula Priest, a biologist and researcher at the International Organization for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), told Folha.
According to the study, fires in tropical and subtropical regions are responsible for 90% of global emissions of PM2.5 (particulate matter with a diameter of less than 2.5 micrometers), degrading air quality and affecting the respiratory health of the population.
The researchers arrived at a total of 28,429,422 cases of 21 forest fire-related, zoonotic and vector-borne diseases, with an incidence rate of 556.96 per 100,000 people, reported in the countries of the Amazon basin from 2001 to 2019.
Forest fire-related diseases accounted for 80.3% (22,821,426 cases), with respiratory diseases being the most prevalent (79.4%), while cardiovascular diseases accounted for 0.87%.
Zoonotic/vector-borne diseases accounted for 19.7% (5,607,996 cases), with malaria accounting for 92.62% of these. Venezuela, Suriname and Peru had the highest incidences. Others such as cutaneous leishmaniasis (5.57%), Chagas disease (1.60%) and visceral leishmaniasis (0.12%) were less common.
"This is very clear evidence of the role of indigenous territories, as well as other forest areas. The sustainable management of traditional peoples manages to provide this service that benefits the health of populations that are not necessarily close to these territories," says Priest.
From 2001 to 2019, the Amazon lost 532,571 km² to fires, with an annual average of 28,030 km², according to the study. Brazil had the largest total area burned (372,281 km²), followed by Bolivia (121,189 km²) and Colombia (21,956 km²).
Proportionally, Bolivia had the greatest extent of burning, with almost 16% of its Amazon area affected, followed by Brazil (8.6%) and Colombia (4%). The accumulated burned area, including repeated fires, reached 923,784 km², with almost 30% of the Bolivian Amazon and 15% of the Brazilian.
The highest number of fires occurred in 2010 and, on average, the areas burned 18 times, indicating recurrent fire. Most of the fires (88.7%) occurred outside the TIs, with 11.3% inside, 7.5% in recognized areas and 3.7% in unrecognized territories.
"We were interested in understanding the effects of indigenous lands because these are areas that are often not prioritized when it comes to conservation, in the eyes of non-technical people," continued Priest.
"I had already seen studies showing that these areas under indigenous protection manage to store a high amount of carbon, important for climate mitigation, and conserve more biodiversity than other protected lands. So we wondered if it was the same for human health."
Heat-related deaths
Another recent study, this one published in Nature Climate Change, evaluated the impact of tropical forest deforestation on human health, involving the Americas, Africa and Asia.
The results indicate a direct link between forest loss, rising local temperatures and increased mortality, with around 28,000 deaths a year - most of which could be avoided, the survey points out.
From 2001 to 2020, around 345 million people were exposed to local warming, with an average increase of 0.27?°C in surface temperature, according to the study led by the University of Leeds (England), in partnership with Fiocruz (Oswaldo Cruz Foundation) and Kwame Nkrumah University (Ghana).
The consequences are most severe in Southeast Asia, with 8 to 11 deaths per 100,000 exposed inhabitants.

urn:contentItem:6FWW-0G43-RRJ4-74SD-00000-00Sun Yat-sen University Researchers Describe Advances in Ecology (Research and application of deep learning object detection methods for forest fire smoke recognition)2025-05-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisECOLOGYSun Yat-sen University Researchers Describe Advances in Ecology (Research and application of deep learning object detection methods for forest fire smoke recognition)


2025 MAY 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Fresh data on ecology are presented in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Sun Yat-sen University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires are severe ecological disasters worldwide that cause extensive ecological destruction and economic losses while threatening biodiversity and human safety. With the escalation of climate change, the frequency and intensity of forest fires are increasing annually, underscoring the urgent need for effective monitoring and early warning systems."


Funders for this research include National Key Research And Development Plan; National Natural Science Foundation of China; Guangdong Key Areas Research And Development Project.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Sun Yat-sen University: "This study investigates the application effectiveness of deep learning-based object detection technology in forest fire smoke recognition by using the YOLOv11x algorithm to develop an efficient fire detection model. The objective is to enhance early fire detection capabilities and mitigate potential damage. To improve the model's applicability and generalizability, two publicly available fire image datasets, WD (Wildfire Dataset) and FFS (Forest Fire Smoke), encompassing various complex scenarios and external conditions, were employed. After 501 training epochs, the model's detection performance was comprehensively evaluated via multiple metrics, including precision, recall, and mean average precision (mAP50 and mAP50-95). The results demonstrate that YOLOv11x excels in bounding box loss (box loss), classification loss (cls loss), and distribution focal loss (dfl loss), indicating effective optimization of object detection performance across multiple dimensions. Specifically, the model achieved a precision of 0.949, a recall of 0.850, an mAP50 of 0.901, and an mAP50-95 of 0.786, highlighting its high detection accuracy and stability. Analysis of the precision-recall (PR) curve revealed an average mAP@0.5 of 0.901, further confirming the effectiveness of YOLOv11x in fire smoke detection. Notably, the mAP@0.5 for the smoke category reached 0.962, whereas for the flame category, it was 0.841, indicating superior performance in smoke detection compared with flame detection. This disparity primarily arises from the distinct visual characteristics of flames and smoke; flames possess more vivid colors and defined shapes, facilitating easier recognition by the model, whereas smoke exhibits more ambiguous and variable textures and shapes, increasing detection difficulty."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "In the test set, 86.89% of the samples had confidence scores exceeding 0.85, further validating the model's reliability. In summary, the YOLOv11x algorithm demonstrates excellent performance and broad application potential in forest fire smoke recognition, providing robust technical support for early fire warning systems and offering valuable insights for the design of intelligent monitoring systems in related fields."
For more information on this research see: Research and application of deep learning object detection methods for forest fire smoke recognition. Scientific Reports, 2025,15(1):1-20. (Scientific Reports - http://www.nature.com/srep/index.html). The publisher for Scientific Reports is Nature Portfolio.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-025-98086-w.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Luhao He, Center for Earth Environment and Earth Resources, Sun Yat-sen University. Additional authors for this research include Yongzhang Zhou, Lei Liu, Yuqing Zhang, Jianhua Ma.
Keywords for this news article include: Sun Yat-sen University, Ecology.

urn:contentItem:6H1R-C1S3-RT19-M1T7-00000-00Government of Canada recognizes 11 new designations of national historic significance2025-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisGovernment of Canada recognizes 11 new designations of national historic significanceTargeted News ServiceOTTAWA, Ontario

Parks Canada issued the following news release:

* * *

Government of Canada recognizes 11 new designations of national historic significance

*

October 22, 2025 Gatineau, Quebec Parks Canada

Today, the Honourable Steven Guilbeault, Minister of Canadian Identity and Culture and Minister responsible for Official Languages, announced 11 designations of persons, places and events of national historic significance under Parks Canada's National Program of Historical Commemoration. These designations honour the diversity of history in Canada. These include:

Places :Seven Oaks House in Winnipeg, Manitoba

Persons: William Kennedy, Charlotte Edith Anderson Monture, Mary Two-Axe Earley, Everett Baker

Events : RCMP Musical Ride, Invention of the Morris Rod-Weeder, Rural Electrification Across Canada, Klippert Case, 1967, Miramichi Fire of 1825, First World War Training at Sarcee Camp

Some highlights from today's announcement include:

Rural Electrification Across Canada: In the early 20 th century, most Canadians lived in rural areas without electricity. Advocacy from women's and farmers' groups helped drive a national push for rural electrification, promoted heavily by utility companies as a modern necessity. Each province took a different approach--from Ontario's publicly owned system to Alberta's cooperatives and Saskatchewan's rapid expansion with farmers. While electrification reshaped rural Canada, some rural residents resisted change, and many First Nations were left out. By the 1970s, nearly all rural households across Canada were connected to central power stations, dramatically improving quality of life and enabling new technologies.

Mary Two-Axe Earley : This Kanien'keha:ka (Mohawk) woman was a trailblazer in the fight for equality for First Nations women. She brought national attention to the gender discrimination in the Indian Act, which stripped women of their Indian status if they married non-status men. Her advocacy led to changes in the law in 1985, allowing women to retain and pass on their status to their children. Two-Axe Earley was the first person to have her status reinstated under the amended Indian Act.

RCMP Musical Ride : With origins in British cavalry traditions, this grand precision performance of scarlet-uniformed police constables on horseback, coordinated with music, was first performed in Regina, North-West Territories (now Saskatchewan), in 1887. The Musical Ride demonstrates the longstanding importance of horsemanship in the history of the federal police force. In 1961, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police created an annual Ride, performing more than one hundred times per year by 1966. Since 1988, officers selected for the Ride serve a three-year term before returning to regular police duties. The Ride now tours across Canada and around the world from May to October.

Miramichi Fire : In October 1825, the Miramichi Fire burned an estimated 15,500 km 2 in northeastern New Brunswick, devastating communities, killing hundreds of people, and leaving thousands more homeless. Roughly PS50,000 was raised to help the entire colony, and this is thought to have been the largest disaster relief effort in pre-Confederation Canadian history. The relief effort strengthened ties between the colony of New Brunswick and Great Britain, the United States, and the colonies of Upper and Lower Canada. This massive forest fire had extensive environmental impacts in New Brunswick, and lasting changes to the ecosystem had an impact on settlers and Mi'kmaq whose lives and livelihoods depended on the lands and waters of the Miramichi region. In the aftermath of the fire, timber exploitation moved to new frontiers while the Miramichi region's industry shifted to the processed lumber trade.

First World War Training at Sarcee Camp: In 1915, reflecting Canada's commitment to the First World War, the government established Sarcee Camp near Calgary on lands recently surrendered by the Tsuut'ina (Sarcee) First Nation. As one of Canada's largest training camps, it introduced over 45,000 Canadians to military life before they were sent overseas. Stone markers on Signal Hill commemorate the thousands who trained there. The camp's creation highlights the pressures faced by First Nations when lands promised for their exclusive use were repurposed for military needs, sparking ongoing conflict. For the Tsuut'ina Nation, the extensive military use of these lands in the 20 th century remains a significant legacy. Sarcee Camp's continued use during the Second World War and the Cold War underscores its lasting role in Canada's military history.

The Government of Canada, through the recommendations from the Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada and Parks Canada, recognizes significant persons, places, and events that have shaped our country as one way of helping Canadians connect with their past. By sharing these stories with Canadians, we hope to foster understanding and reflection on the diverse histories, cultures, legacies, and realities of Canada's past and present.

urn:contentItem:6GRN-SV33-RXJ5-820D-00000-00Misti fire is still active and devastated 48 hectares of natural grasslands2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisMisti fire is still active and devastated 48 hectares of natural grasslands


The forest fire that started on Saturday on the slopes of the Misti volcano continues and has already destroyed at least 48 hectares of natural cover, according to information from the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER).


The fire spread to the higher parts of the districts of Miraflores, Mariano Melgar and Chiguata. The flames were further fanned by the wind and the dryness of the terrain.
The devastation is greatest in Miraflores, where 40 hectares have been lost. In Mariano Melgar the flames devastated five, and in Chiguata three. No human casualties have been reported.
In the early hours of the morning, the COER met with first response institutions such as the Forestry Police, Serfor, Sernanp, the Red Cross and the Peruvian Army. The latter brought shovels, rakes, fire extinguishers and hydrodynamic backpacks, as well as troops to reinforce the work in the field.
The brigades are trying to suffocate the active outbreaks and remove the earth to prevent the fire from reactivating, while drones with thermal cameras follow the advance of the flames.
In addition, during the work they found people setting fires in bushes, despite the fact that the fire was active.
PROBLEMS
In addition, during the coordination work, a person was found setting fire in front of the brigade members, despite the fact that they have been fighting for several hours to control the flames that have caused damage to the ecosystem of the area.
The person was removed from the area and the authorities present made a call to the population to avoid these practices in natural areas, as they can cause damage to nature.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-844C-00000-00Sanchez travels to Asturias to know the evolution of the Degaña fire2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:35ZLexisNexisSanchez travels to Asturias to know the evolution of the Degaña fire


The President of the Government, Pedro Sánchez, will travel this Friday morning to Asturias to see on the ground the evolution of the forest fire in Degaña, according to government sources.


It will be the fourth community affected by the fires that Pedro Sánchez will visit after having been in Galicia, Castilla y León and Extremadura in recent days.
The last visit made by Sánchez to territories affected by the fires was this Tuesday in Molezuelas de la Carballeda (Zamora), although on this occasion he was not accompanied by the president of Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco.
On Tuesday morning, Sánchez also made a visit to the Advanced Command Post of the Jarilla fire (Cáceres) and there he was accompanied by the regional president, María Guardiola.
In the case of the visit to Galicia last Sunday morning, Sanchez went to the areas affected by the fires in the province of Ourense and met with the president of the Xunta, Alfonso Rueda, and with the minister Grande-Marlaska.
Sánchez appeared at a press conference with Rueda and there he proposed a "great pact" of State for the "mitigation and adaptation" to the climatic emergency, as a response to the wave of fires that Spain is suffering.
In addition, he stressed that "a deep reflection" should be made on how to "resize" the capacities, not only in response but also in the prevention of "everything that has to do with the climate emergency".
The President also told the Galician society that the General State Administration and the Government will do "everything and more" so that they can return "as soon as possible to the normality of their lives.
In Castilla y León, Sánchez also visited on Sunday the area affected by the forest fire in Orallo (León), in the surroundings of Villablino, where he was accompanied by the president of the Junta, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco; the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska; and the delegate of the Government, Nicanor Sen.
In this visit Sánchez did not appear before the media, as he had done in Galicia. Fernández Mañueco, for his part, took the opportunity to demand more means from the Army and the European Civil Protection Mechanism to reinforce the operation before the fires facing Castilla y León, where, precisely, León is one of the provinces with the most serious situation.
